explanation: A chemical that changes the sex hormone testosterone into a substance called dihydrotestosterone. This hormone can cause the prostate gland to grow abnormally.
A flat sheet of muscles on the front of the abdomen, between the ribcage and the pelvis.
A procedure to remove excess abdominal skin and tighten the underlying stomach muscles. Also known as a tummy tuck.
Movement of a body part, such as an arm or leg, away from the center of the body.
A form of treatment that uses electrical energy, heat, cold, alcohol, or other modalities to destroy a small section of damaged tissue.
A scraping or rubbing away of the skin or other surface.
Pus that collects in a pocket of swollen, red tissue. Often occurs on the surface of the skin.
A tooth or implant to which a fixed prosthesis is anchored.
Psychotherapy techniques that use mindfulness to help a person recognize and accept thoughts and feelings but not be controlled by them.
The eye's ability to focus on objects that are close.
Abbreviation for angiotensin-converting enzyme, an enzyme that converts the inactive form of the protein angiotensin (angiotensin I) to its active form—angiotensin II.
Abbreviation of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, a drug used to treat high blood pressure and congestive heart failure.
A curved, bowl-shaped depression in the outer part of the hipbone. The ball-shaped portion at the top of the thighbone fits into this space to form the hip joint.
The main breakdown product of alcohol metabolism; accumulation of it in the bloodstream may produce flushing (a feeling of heat in the face or chest) and vomiting.
A common, over-the-counter drug used to reduce fever and relieve mild to moderate pain, but which does not reduce redness or swelling (inflammation).
A neurotransmitter (a chemical messenger that sends signals between brain cells) that plays roles in attention, learning, and memory.
A band of connective tissue that connects the calf muscle to the heel bone. This tissue is prone to swelling and/or rupture.
A condition in which the stomach produces little or no acid. This can affect digestion, cause stomach pain, and keep the body from absorbing vitamins and nutrients.
An inflammatory disease resulting from excess sebum production, follicle plugging, and increased bacterial production.

Usually abbreviated as AIDS. This is the most advanced stage of infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which can severely weaken the immune system. People with AIDS get many infections, often from diseases that don’t affect people with healthy immune systems.
The term given to the brain's absorption of new information to begin creating a memory.
A shoulder joint that connects the clavicle to the scapula.
One of the proteins that allows cells to move and muscles to contract.
Scaly pink or red-brown raised spots or patches on the skin caused by overexposure to the sun. Actinic keratosis may be a precursor to skin cancer.
A strategy for managing early prostate cancer in which a man has regular checkups but does not undergo treatment until the disease shows signs of worsening.
Using the thumb or fingers to apply pressure to particular spots, or pressure points, on the body in order to relieve pain.
A treatment based on Chinese medicine. Thin needles are inserted into the skin at specific points on the body. This therapy is used to treat pain and various health problems and to reduce stress.
A condition that comes on suddenly, often with severe, but short-lived symptoms.
Severe pain that occurs suddenly and usually lasts a short while.
A sudden inability to empty the bladder. Causes include an enlarged prostate gland (in men) or bladder muscle problems.
The ability of an organism to change genetically in a way that allows it to deal better with its environmental conditions.
The ability of the body to learn to fight specific infections after being exposed to the germs that cause them.
Loss of control over indulging in a substance or performing an action or behavior, and continued craving for it despite negative consequences.
Movement of a body part toward or across the midline.
A type of cancer that grows in the layer of tissue known as the epithelium. This tissue lines organs and structures in the body, protecting or enclosing them.
A benign growth found in the layer of cells that lines certain organs (epithelial cells).
An energy-storing molecule that is found in all human cells. Usually abbreviated as ATP.
An estimate of the amount of a nutrient needed by healthy people. The Adequate Intake is used when there isn’t enough information to set a recommended dietary allowance (RDA).
A band of scar-like tissue that forms between two surfaces inside the body, connecting tissues or organs which are not normally connected.
Fat-filled tissue.
Extra therapy given after a primary treatment, to increase the effectiveness of the primary treatment. For example, using chemotherapy after surgery or radiation treatment for cancer.
Glands that sit on top of each kidney and secrete stress hormones.
Stress hormone that puts the body on high alert. Changes include faster heartbeat, more rapid breathing, greater energy, and higher blood pressure. Also called epinephrine.
Centers providing daytime services to adults who need supervision, social support, or assistance with daily activities.
An ingredient in a medicinal product (herb, supplement, or prescription drug), which dilutes the purity of the product and does not contribute to its therapeutic effects.

term: advance care directive (or advance medical directive)
explanation: A legal document that describes the kind of medical care a person want if an accident or illness leaves him or her unable to make or communicate decisions.
A pattern of falling asleep and waking up earlier than wanted that worsens progressively over time.
Any process that requires oxygen. Often used to describe a form of exercise, aerobic exercise.
Physical activity that speeds breathing, improves heart and lung function, and offers many other health benefits. Examples include brisk walking, running, or cycling.
Excessive swallowing of air.
Licensed skin care professional who performs procedures such as deep cleansing, low-grade chemical peels, microdermabrasion, and postsurgical skin care.
Clouding of the lens of the eye that can occur months or years after cataract surgery.
The slight loss of memory and slowing of the brain’s information processing that occurs with normal aging.
A potentially blinding condition that destroys sharp central vision.
A rare disease in which a person can’t recognize objects, shapes, or people. Often due to a brain or neurological condition.
1) A substance that triggers a physiological response when it combines with a receptor. 2) A muscle whose contraction is opposed by another muscle.
Fear and avoidance of public places and open spaces.
abbreviation for acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, the most advanced stage of infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
A loss of brain function that occurs rapidly in some AIDS patients; marked by forgetfulness, difficulty thinking, and trouble focusing.
A group of inherited conditions that typically appear as a reduction or absence of melanin pigments in the skin, hair, and eyes.
A protein made by the liver. Abnormal levels of this substance may indicate liver or kidney disease.
High amounts of albumin (a protein made by the liver) in the urine, possibly indicating kidney dysfunction.
Continuing consumption of alcohol despite alcohol-related social or interpersonal problems.
A liver enzyme that metabolizes alcohol into a substance called acetaldehyde, which is toxic. Sometimes referred to as ADH.

A chronic, progressive disease characterized by excessive and often compulsive drinking, impaired control over drinking, use of alcohol despite adverse consequences, and withdrawal symptoms when alcohol use is discontinued. Also known as alcoholism.

Another term for alcohol dependence: A chronic, progressive disease characterized by excessive and often compulsive drinking, impaired control over drinking, use of alcohol despite adverse consequences, and withdrawal symptoms when alcohol use is discontinued. Also known as alcoholism.
A hormone secreted by the adrenal glands that helps regulate blood pressure by controlling sodium and potassium levels in the body.
A drug used to treat and prevent osteoporosis by slowing bone loss.
Another term for the gastrointestinal, or digestive, tract.
One of two or more versions of a gene. Different alleles produce variations in inherited characteristics, such as eye color.
A substance such as fur, pollen, or dust that produces an allergic reaction.
Having a sensitivity to one or more normally harmless substances.

A seasonal or year-round allergic condition marked by sneezing, runny nose, and congestion. The most common type of allergy, it is caused by an IgE-mediated immune response to inhaled airborne allergens.
An immune system reaction (for example, rash, fever, sneezing, or headaches) to something that is normally harmless.
Pain resulting from something not normally painful, such as a light touch.
An autoimmune condition that appears as patchy hair loss on the scalp that may result in permanent hair loss.
Hair loss that involves the entire scalp.
Hair loss that involves the entire body.

A group of drugs that lower blood pressure by blocking the effects of adrenaline or adrenaline-like substances on cells' alpha receptors. Also used to treat some prostate gland problems. Alpha blockers are also known as alpha-adrenergic antagonists, alpha-adrenergic blocking agents, and alpha-adrenergic blockers.
Cells in the pancreas that produce the hormone glucagon.
Fruit-derived acids used in creams and lotions to act as exfoliants.
A type of brain wave generated when a person is relaxed, awake, and receiving no visual input (eyes closed or in the dark).
Abnormal deep sleep; also called non-restorative sleep.
A drug used to treat Type 2 diabetes.
The part of the jawbone that supports the teeth.
Tiny air sacs in the lung. They are where oxygen enters and carbon dioxide leaves the bloodstream.
A progressive brain disease that causes memory loss, impaired thinking, and personality changes.
Able to walk; not confined to a bed.
Abbreviation for age-related macular degeneration, a potentially blinding condition that destroys sharp central vision.
Unusual memory loss or forgetfulness.
The surgical removal of a limb or other body part.
A tool used to check for vision problems, particularly macular degeneration. The grid looks like graph paper with a dot in the center.
Part of the brain involved in memory and emotion.
An enzyme secreted by the pancreas that breaks starch into sugar.
A protein that collects in tissues when certain diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease, are present.
Any process that doesn’t require oxygen. Often refers to a form of short, high intensity exercise, known as anaerobic exercise.
Exercise that improves the efficiency of energy-producing systems that do not rely on oxygen. Examples include sprinting and weight lifting.
The active growth phase of the hair-growth cycle.
The last inch of the large intestine, leading to the anal opening.
Absence of pain.
A drug or other substance such as aspirin, acetaminophen, or morphine that is used to relieve pain.
Differences in how a test is done, for example how a sample is prepared, which can affect test outcomes.
A severe allergic reaction, causing symptoms spanning from itching and swelling to trouble breathing, convulsions, shock, and coma.
Any of a group of male sex hormones, including testosterone, that controls male characteristics such as beard growth.
Female- and male-pattern baldness. The condition appears to involve a heightened response by the hair follicle to androgen levels in the body.
Prostate cancer that no longer responds to hormone therapy.
Having a lower than normal amount of red blood cells or hemoglobin (an oxygen-carrying protein inside red blood cells), leading to low energy, weakness, and other symptoms.
A birth defect in which an infant is born without most of the brain or without the skull bones covering the brain.
Temporarily blocking sensation, especially the feeling of pain.
A bulge or swelling on a portion of a blood vessel, due to weakness in the wall of that vessel.
Temporary chest pain that occurs when the heart isn’t getting enough oxygen and blood, usually occurring in response to physical activity or stress.
The formation of new blood vessels.
A test that shows how blood moves through the blood vessels and heart. It uses x-rays and the injection of a fluid called a contrast agent that can be seen on the x-rays.
A procedure used to open blocked or narrowed arteries, most commonly by inserting a thin tube, or catheter, into the affected artery and inflating a balloon.
A protein that raises blood pressure by narrowing blood vessels and causing the kidneys to store more sodium and water.
An inactive form of the protein angiotensin. It is the precursor to the active form, angiotensin II.
The active form of the protein angiotensin, which raises blood pressure by narrowing blood vessels and causing the kidneys to store more sodium and water.
A class of drugs that blocks the effects of angiotensin. Like ACE inhibitors, they keep coronary arteries open, lower blood pressure, and reduce the heart's workload.
An enzyme that converts the inactive form of the protein angiotensin (angiotensin I) to its active form—angiotensin II. Usually abbreviated as ACE.

A drug used to treat high blood pressure and congestive heart failure. These drugs stop the production of angiotensin II. This lowers blood pressure and reduces the heart's workload. Usually abbreviated as ACE inhibitor.
A test that compares blood pressure at the ankle with blood pressure at the elbow. A difference between the two indicates the presence of peripheral artery disease.
Means crooked or bent; refers to stiffening of a joint.
A disease that leads to swelling between the disks of the spine and in the joints where the pelvis and spine meet. Causes back pain and stiffness and can limit movement.
Term used to describe ring or circle shaped objects or body parts.
The tough outer covering of the discs in the spine.
Abnormal functioning of the anus and rectum, causing constipation or the inability to control bowel movements.
An eating disorder in which a person has an intense fear of gaining weight and severely limits calories to the point of near starvation.
The muscle opposing the major muscle required to do a task. It works to help balance movement and ward off injury.
A heart attack affecting the front of the heart.
A drug that blocks or interferes with the activity of male sex hormones.
A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria.
A protein made by the immune system to protect the body from harmful substances, called antigens.
A substance that helps prevent blood from clotting.

Drugs that diminish the blood's ability to clot. Anticoagulants are sometimes called blood thinners even though they do not thin the blood. Commonly used anticoagulant drugs include heparin and warfarin.
Drugs used to treat seizures.
An antibody used to help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis.
A psychiatric drug used to treat mood disorders, such as depression.
A drug that prevents nausea and vomiting.
Any substance that the body sees as harmful or foreign, causing the immune system to form antibodies in defense.
Specialized white blood cells that detect harmful substances in the body and then signal other immune system defenders (known as T-cells) to mount a defense.
Medications that treat allergies and reduce symptoms such as sneezing and itching by blocking histamine, the substance in the body which causes these symptoms.
Medications used to lower and control high blood pressure.
A type of asthma medication that reduces swelling in airways and prevents muscles near the airways from tightening.
A general term for antibiotics and other drugs that fight microscopic organisms in the body, such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites.
Substances that protect the body from molecules that damage cells (free radicals); examples include beta carotene, vitamin C, vitamin A, and vitamin E.
Medications or other substances that prevent blood cells called platelets from clustering and forming blood clots.
A drug used to treat schizophrenia and other severe mental health disorders; relieves symptoms such as delusions and hallucinations.
Substances used on wounds to prevent or treat infection; they kill or slow the growth of disease-causing organisms, such as bacteria, on the surface of the body.
Drug that relieves cramps and muscle spasms.
Drugs used to treat an overactive thyroid.
The external opening at the end of digestive tract where feces are expelled.
The large artery emerging from the heart's left ventricle that distributes blood to the body.
A valve on the left side of the heart that acts as a one-way gate, opening to allow blood to leave the left ventricle and closing to prevent blood from leaking back into that ventricle.
Difficulty speaking or comprehending language; a common occurrence after a stroke affecting the left hemisphere of the brain, where language is processed.
A temporary pause in breathing during sleep that can be very brief or can last so long that the amount of oxygen in the blood drops dangerously low.
Proteins that combine with cholesterol and triglyceride to form lipoproteins.
A process of programmed cell death in which redundant or flawed cells destroy themselves.
A normal brain protein that under certain circumstances produces beta amyloid, abnormal protein deposited in the brain in Alzheimer’s disease. Usually abbreviated as APP.
A brain disorder in which a person cannot perform certain actions, such as combing hair, picking up a pencil, or speaking, even though they want to and have the physical ability to do so.
Clear fluid that fills the front part of the eye.

Abbreviation for angiotensin II receptor blockers, a class of drugs that blocks the effects of angiotensin. Like ACE inhibitors, they keep coronary arteries open, lower blood pressure, and reduce the heart's workload.
A virus transmitted by mosquitoes or other member of the arthropod phylum.
The state of being awake or reactive to stimuli through one or more of the five senses.
The small muscle associated with an individual hair follicle that enables hair to stand on end.
An abnormal heart rhythm caused by a disturbance in the heart’s electrical system.
The pressure that the artery walls exert on blood flow; in general, the less elastic the arteries, the greater the arterial resistance and the higher the blood pressure.
A test that uses x-rays and a special dye to see inside arteries.
Small, muscular branches of arteries.

A term encompassing a variety of conditions in which artery walls thicken and become less flexible. Sometimes called hardening of the arteries. Arteriosclerosis occurs when cholesterol-rich plaque forms on the inner lining of arteries (atherosclerosis), when artery walls become calcified, or when high blood pressure thickens the muscular wall of arteries.
Abnormal connections between veins and arteries, usually caused by a birth defect.
A blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart and to various parts of the body.
A prefix meaning "joint.''
A condition in which joints are inflamed, causing pain, stiffness, swelling, and sometimes loss of movement.
A procedure to drain fluid from a joint using a syringe.
Joining together two bones to reduce pain and provide stability to a damaged, arthritic, or painful joint.
Joint disease or disorder.
Surgically rebuilding or replacing a joint, usually to relieve arthritis or fix an abnormality.
A procedure where a surgeon makes a small cut in the skin and inserts tiny lenses, lighting, and other instruments to diagnose or repair joint problems.
Smooth white tissue that covers the ends of bones where they come together to form joints.
Bony projections on vertebra.
A life-threatening lack of oxygen due to drowning, choking, or an obstruction of the airways.
Breathing in a foreign object. Also, the process of suctioning fluid, tissue, or other substances from the body.
A drug that relieves pain, fever, and swelling, and inhibits the formation of blood clots.

Live-in facilities for adults who need help with certain things, but do not need round-the-clock care. They provide residents with supervision and certain services, such as meals, transportation, or help with dressing, grooming, and other daily activities.
The part of the cerebral cortex involved in processing information, rather than movement or sensory experiences.
A disease that inflames and narrows airways, causing wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and tightness in the chest.
Blurry vision caused by an irregular curve in the cornea of the eye.
A substance that contracts skin tissues and shrinks pores.
Showing no signs or symptoms of disease, whether or not disease is present.
The absence of electrical activity in the heart.
Being unable to control movement; symptoms include shaking and an unsteady walk.
An abnormal build-up of fatty plaque inside an artery.
The buildup of fatty deposits (plaque) in the walls of arteries, causing narrowing and reduced blood flow; the disease responsible for most heart attacks and many strokes.
A mixture of fats, cholesterol, and other tissue that builds up on artery walls.
A type of stroke that occurs when a large artery to the brain is completely blocked by the formation of a clot.
A foot infection caused by fungus; symptoms include cracking and peeling skin and itchiness. Also known as tinea pedis.
Another name for the topmost vertebra of the neck, which lies just beneath the skull. Also called C-1.
Having an inherited predisposition to allergies.
A long-term skin condition, most common in babies and children, in which areas of the skin are dry, itchy, red, and may crack. Also known as eczema.
A seasonal or year-round allergy marked by sneezing, runny nose, and congestion.
The inherited tendency to develop allergies.
Abbreviation for adenosine triphosphate, an energy-storing molecule that is found in all human cells.
The upper chambers of the heart. There are two of these—the right atrium and the left atrium.
A disorder in which the two upper chambers of the heart beat fast and erratically. Because blood isn’t pumped out of these chambers fully, it may pool and form clots that could lead to a stroke.

Also known as the AV node. A major part of the electrical system in the heart that acts as a gateway between the atria and the ventricles. An electrical signal generated by the sinoatrial node (the heart's natural pacemaker) moves through the heart until it reaches the atrioventricular node, a cluster of cells at the bottom of the right atrium. The AV node delays the signal before it is passed to the ventricles. This lets the atria fully contract before the ventricles contract.
One of the heart's two upper chambers (the plural form is atria). The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the body; the left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs.
Wasting away of an organ or tissue due to undernourishment, disease, or aging.
An overgrowth of abnormally shaped cells in areas of the breast that produce milk (lobules). atypical lobular hyperplasia is not cancerous but may become cancer.
A chart that shows a person’s ability to hear at different pitches or frequencies.
A health professional who assesses hearing and fits hearing aids.
A complete hearing test that involves listening to sounds of different frequencies and volume.
A nerve in the inner ear that transmits information about sound to the brain.
Sensations such as chills, flashes of light, or a blind spot that come just before the occurrence of medical problems such as migraines or seizures.
Proteins created by the immune system that mistakenly target healthy cells, tissues, or organs.
A disease in which the immune system mistakenly identifies healthy tissues and organs as threats and responds by attacking and destroying them.
When the body’s immune system mistakenly views the body’s own tissues and organs as foreign invaders and attacks them.
Removal of fat from one part of the body to use as filler in another part, for example, to fill wrinkles and lines in the face and lips.
The part of the nervous system that controls involuntary actions, such as blood pressure or breathing. It also plays an important role in the fight or flight response to danger.
Damage to the nerves that control involuntary body functions, such as digestion, heart rate, and bladder and bowel function.
Surgically opening and examining a body after death to see if any diseases are present and to determine the cause of death.

Abbreviation for atrioventricular node, a major part of the electrical system in the heart that acts as a gateway between the atria and the ventricles. An electrical signal generated by the sinoatrial node (the heart's natural pacemaker) moves through the heart until it reaches the atrioventricular node, a cluster of cells at the bottom of the right atrium. The AV node delays the signal before it is passed to the ventricles. This lets the atria fully contract before the ventricles contract.
The tearing away of one part of the body from another—for example, a tendon tearing away from a bone.
The armpit.
The second vertebra of the neck (from the skull); also called the C-2 vertebra.
The long, slender extension of a nerve cell that conducts electrical impulses away from the nerve's cell body and on to nearby nerves.
The end of an axon.
White blood cells that come from bone marrow, and produce antibodies to fight off disease.
Tiny single-celled organisms. Some bacteria cause disease, although most are harmless.
Ability to maintain equilibrium while stationary or moving.
A procedure to open clogged heart arteries. A surgeon inserts and inflates a tiny balloon. It widens the blocked artery then expands a small wire mesh tube to keep the artery open.
A surgical procedure to open a narrowed vessel or tube, such as the urethra, esophagus, or artery. A small, deflated balloon is inserted into the area and inflated to widen it.
One of several types of weight loss surgery performed on people who are dangerously overweight, to restrict or reduce food intake and/or absorption.

An imaging test that allows doctors to see the inside of the esophagus and upper stomach. It involves swallowing a barium solution, which coats the esophagus and makes it possible for x-rays to see the inside of the intestine.
The abnormal growth of stomach or small intestine cells in the esophagus, resulting from damage caused by the reflux of stomach acid; occasionally may transform into cancer.
The most common skin cancer. Basal cell carcinoma doesn’t spread to internal organs.
Clusters of nerve cells deep in the brain that play an important role in movement.
An electrocardiogram (EKG) tracing taken in a healthy individual for later comparison to subsequent EKGs.
The artery that supplies blood to the cerebellum, the brainstem, and the back of the brain.
Harmless; often used to refer to a tumor that is not cancerous and does not usually spread.
A severe headache that occurs when orgasm is reached.
A noncancerous enlargement of the prostate gland that obstructs the flow of urine. Often called BPH.
Anti-anxiety medications that work by helping to maintain levels of the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain.
The period of grief and mourning after a death.
A nervous system or heart disorder caused by lack of the vitamin thiamine (B1).
A test to try to reproduce heartburn symptoms; used by doctors to diagnose GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease).

A class of drugs that slow the heartbeat, lessen the force of each contraction, and reduce the contraction of blood vessels in the heart, brain, and throughout the body by blocking the action of beta-adrenergic substances such as adrenaline (epinephrine) at the beta receptor. Beta blockers, also known as beta adrenergic blocking agents, are used to treat many cardiovascular conditions, including abnormal heart rhythms, angina, and high blood pressure. They also improve survival after a heart attack.
A richly colored compound (red, yellow, or orange) found in many plants, fruits, and vegetables that the body can convert into vitamin A.
Cells that make and secrete insulin; located in the islets of Langerhans of the pancreas.
A medication that opens airways by relaxing the muscles around the airway; used to treat asthma or COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).
An abnormal protein deposited in the brain in Alzheimer’s disease.
Medications that stop the liver from making excess glucose (sugar) and improve sensitivity to insulin.
A thick, yellow-green fluid produced by the liver that aids in digestion.
Fatty substances made by the gallbladder that aid in digestion.
A machine that helps people get more air into their lungs when sleeping by increasing the pressure or force of air when breathing in; often used to treat sleep apnea.
Heavy bouts of drinking interspersed with periods of abstinence; often refers to the consumption of five or more alcoholic beverages within one day.
The ability of both eyes to focus on an object and form a single visual image.
A type of dementia caused when blood flow is interrupted to the white matter of the brain, which lies beneath the cerebral cortex.
How quickly and completely the body can absorb and use a nutrient.
A natural compound found in soybeans that may help prevent cancer from spreading. It is a type of flavonoid.

Usually used regarding prostate cancer. It refers to a post-treatment increase in the level of prostate-specific antigen in the bloodstream, indicating that prostate cancer has recurred or spread following the original treatment. Also called biochemical failure.
An treatment that helps people learn to gain control over normally unconscious body functions, such as breathing and heart rates.
Normal fluctuations over time in the levels of a substance being measured (such as cholesterol).
A distinctive biological indicator of an event, process, or condition.
The removal of a small piece of tissue from the body for examination under a microscope.
Medications, including alendronate and etidronate, used to prevent and treat osteoporosis by slowing the breakdown of bone.
An episode of temporary memory loss resulting from the ingestion of alcohol or other drugs.
Where the bladder and urethra meet.
Cosmetic surgery to improve the appearance of droopy eyelids by removing excess skin and fat.
A small pocket of fluid that develops between the upper layers of skin; often caused by friction or burns.
Substance that prevents a biological activity or process.
A measure of the amount of alcohol in the blood.
A coagulated mass that occurs when blood cells stick together and form a solid.
The force blood exerts against the walls of the arteries. Optimal blood pressure is less than 120/80 mm Hg.
A test that measures levels of urea in the blood to assess how well the kidneys are functioning.
Hollow tubes that transport blood throughout the body; includes arteries, veins, and capillaries.
Abbreviation for bone mineral density, the amount of mineralized bone tissue in a given area.

Abbreviation for body-mass index, a measure of body fat estimated from a person’s height and weight. A healthy BMI is defined as 18.5 to 24.9. BMI = weight (in kilograms) divided by height (in meters) squared. Using English units, multiply weight in pounds by 703, then divide the result by height in inches, and divide that result by height in inches.

A measure of body fat estimated from a person’s height and weight. A healthy BMI is defined as 18.5 to 24.9. BMI = weight (in kilograms) divided by height (in meters) squared. Using English units, multiply weight in pounds by 703, then divide the result by height in inches, and divide that result by height in inches.
A soft mass of chewed food. Alternatively, a single large dose of a medication given intravenously.
The total amount of bone tissue in the body.
The amount of mineralized bone tissue in a given area.
A test in which radioactive material is injected into a person's bloodstream to help produce images of bones; often used to detect cancer or bone diseases.
Stomach growling; the rumbling noises caused by gas moving through the intestine.
Brand name for a drug made of botulinum toxin type A that is injected into muscles and weakens them to ease the appearance of wrinkles.
Hard, bony growths that form on the middle joints of fingers in people with osteoarthritis.
The small or large intestine.
Abbreviation for benign prostatic hyperplasia, a noncancerous enlargement of the prostate gland that obstructs the flow of urine.
A network of nerves that are rooted at the cervical spine and provide sensation and movement to the shoulder and arm.
Treatment in which a surgeon implants seeds or pellets of radioactive material in the body to destroy cancer cells.
A slow heart rate, usually below 60 beats per minute.

Technologies that allow doctors to view the structure of the brain or see how different parts of the brain function; examples include computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), functional MRI (fMRI), and positron emission tomography (PET).
The part of the brain that connects the brain with the spinal cord and controls movement, sensation, and reflexes.
Electrical impulses generated by the firing of nerve cells in the brain (neurons).
Cosmetic surgery to increase the size of the breasts.
A form of meditation aimed at bringing on a state of relaxation.
The part of the brain (in the frontal lobe of the left hemisphere) responsible for language comprehension and speech.
The airways that connect the lungs to the trachea (windpipe) and allow air to pass into and out of the lungs.
A small airway in the respiratory system that connects to the alveoli (air sacs); a branch of the bronchial tubes.
Medication that eases breathing by relaxing the muscles surrounding the bronchial tubes.
Unusual sound, heard through a stethoscope, that blood makes when it rushes past an obstruction, like a blockage in an artery.
A bump of bone or tissue that forms at the big toe joint, causing inflammation and considerable pain.
A small, painful bony bump that forms on the outside of the foot, at the base of the small toe.
A protective, fluid-filled sac located in or near the joints that cushions the movement of bone against tendons, skin, and muscle.
Pain and swelling of the bursa, the small fluid filled pads that act as cushions in or near the joints.
A procedure used to divert the flow of blood or other fluids. When referring to the heart, shorthand for coronary artery bypass surgery, used to divert blood flow around a blocked coronary artery.
Abbreviation for coronary artery bypass graft. Surgery to improve blood flow to the heart by diverting blood around a blocked artery.
The buildup of calcium deposits in soft tissue, causing it to harden. Often seen in breast tissue by mammography or in coronary arteries by x-ray or cardiac CT scans.
A hormone that can stimulate bone growth and is sometimes used to treat osteoporosis.
A mineral that the body needs for many vital functions, including bone formation, regulation of heart rate and blood pressure, and muscle contraction.

A class of drugs that lowers blood pressure, slows the heart rate, and decreases the heart's need for oxygen by blocking the movement of calcium into the heart and the muscle cells surrounding blood vessels.
Hardened, thick skin that forms after repeated friction; often found on hands and the bottom of feet.
The unit for measuring the amount of energy in food.
One of two types of tissue that form bone; this type is commonly found at the center of long bones and makes up a large part of the hip and spine. Also known as trabecular bone.
A group of diseases in which abnormal cells grow in an uncontrolled way, sometimes forming tumors.
The body’s smallest blood vessels; they deliver oxygen and nutrients to tissues.
An chemical found in hot chili peppers that is used in some pain relief creams.
The sugars and starches in food that provide the body with most of its fuel. Carbohydrates are one of three primary nutrients along with fats and proteins.
Keeping track of the grams of carbohydrates eaten in order to control weight.
An odorless, colorless gas that is toxic to humans and animals at high levels; it is produced by cars, furnaces, fireplaces, and other equipment powered by combustion.
Any substance that can cause cancer.
The process by which a normal cell becomes cancerous.
A cancerous tumor that develops in the tissue that lines the organs of the body (the epithelium).
Pertaining to the heart.

The sudden cessation of contractions capable of circulating blood to the body and brain. Also called sudden cardiac arrest. Cardiac arrest usually occurs as a result of a rapid ventricular rhythm (ventricular tachycardia) or a chaotic one (ventricular fibrillation). Death occurs within minutes unless cardiopulmonary resuscitation and defibrillation are available.

A procedure to diagnose or treat heart problems; a long, thin, flexible tube is inserted into a blood vessel in the arm, neck, or upper thigh and maneuvered into the heart to evaluate various heart functions.
Heart-muscle cells.
The amount of blood the heart is able to pump into circulation; specifically measured as the amount of blood the left side of the heart can pump in one minute.
A pacemaker-based therapy for heart failure that improves the heart's pumping efficiency by coordinating (resynchronizing) the beat of the ventricles.
When fluid or blood pools within the sac surrounding the heart, squeezing the heart and interfering with its ability to pump.
Temporarily stopping the heart during heart surgery.
Pertaining to the heart and lungs.
The use of a machine (heart/lung machine) to circulate and oxygenate the blood while surgery is performed on the heart.
A pump used to oxygenate and circulate blood through the body while the heart is stopped during open-heart surgery.
A combination of chest compressions and mouth-to-mouth breathing that keep oxygenated blood circulating to the brain and tissues. Commonly known as CPR.
A component of physical fitness that relates to the ability of the circulatory and respiratory systems to supply oxygen during sustained physical activity. Also known as cardiorespiratory fitness.
Pertaining to the heart and blood vessels.

The use of an electrical shock to stop an abnormal heart rhythm (an arrhythmia) and restore a normal one (sinus rhythm). Cardioversion can be external, using pads applied to the chest, or internal, from a pacemaker-like device called an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD).
An herb said to expel gas from the digestive system, easing stomach discomfort.
Compounds such as lycopene and beta carotene that give red, yellow, and orange color to certain plants.
One of two major blood vessels found on either side of the neck. The carotid arteries supply blood to the brain.
Narrowing of the carotid artery by the buildup of plaque. Sometimes called carotid artery stenosis. It is a major risk factor for ischemic stroke.
An abnormal sound heard with a stethoscope in the carotid artery; people who have carotid bruits have a greater risk of having a stroke.
An ultrasound image of the carotid arteries.
Surgery to remove fatty plaque buildup from the carotid artery and restore blood flow to the brain.
A condition that occurs when the median nerve, which runs from the forearm through the hand, is compressed; symptoms include pain, tingling, and numbness, as well as hand weakness.
Stiff connective tissue that provides support to other tissues and cushions joints.
A joint in which the bones are firmly connected by cartilage, so that only slight movement is possible.
A research study that compares one group of people with a particular disease to a very similar group that does not have the same disease.
The transition phase of the hair-growth cycle.
Sudden paralysis of some or all muscles brought on by laughter, anger, fright, or strong emotions; a hallmark of narcolepsy.
A clouding or fogging of the lens of the eye that may blur or tint vision.
A strong emotional reaction to a minor event.
An agent with a strong laxative effect.
A thin tube that is inserted into the body to provide or drain fluids, or to carry tiny surgical instruments and cameras in minimally invasive surgeries.
A positively charged ion; cations in the body include sodium, potassium, and magnesium.
A bundles of nerve roots that look like a horse’s tail, located at the end of the spinal cord.
Intense, long-lasting burning pain usually caused by damage to a peripheral nerve.
A hole in the tooth caused by advanced decay.
Abbreviation for complete blood count—tests run on a blood sample to provide information on red cells, white cells, and platelets.
Abbreviation for coronary care unit, a ward in a hospital that provides specialized care and extensive monitoring for patients with heart problems.

A disease characterized by damage to the small intestine caused by an oversensitivity to gluten, a protein found in wheat, rye, and barley. Celiac disease can interfere with the proper absorption of nutrients from food.
A network of nerves in the upper abdomen; medication is sometimes injected here as part of a therapy to ease pain called a nerve block.
The basic building block of all living organisms.
The end stage in the life of a cell when the cell can no longer divide.
A type of immune response mounted against viruses, certain types of parasites, and perhaps cancer cells.
The layer of tooth material that covers the root.
A lack of concentration or alertness as well as a sense of lethargy and loss of motivation; involves the central nervous system.
The brain, brainstem, and spinal cord.
A disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops during sleep, because the brain doesn’t properly signal the muscles that control breathing.
The part of the brain that controls coordinated movement.
A weakening and ballooning of the wall of an artery in the brain.
An invasive imaging procedure used to make detailed x-ray pictures of the blood vessels in the brain; dye is injected into the carotid arteries to highlight the blood vessels on x-rays.
The part of the brain involved in all forms of conscious experience, including thought, language, and memory.
Bleeding in the brain caused by the rupture of a blood vessel; another term for hemorrhagic stroke.
A type of stroke caused when a blood vessel that supplies blood to the brain is blocked by a blood clot.
Pertaining to the blood vessels in the brain.
The medical term for a stroke.
A substance that helps keep dirt out of the ear and lubricates the skin in the ear. More commonly known as earwax.
A pinched nerve, causing sharp pain, tingling, and numbness in the areas served by the nerve.
The part of the spine located in the neck and consisting of the top seven vertebrae.
Inflammatory arthritis involving the neck portion of the spine.
Headache related to neck problems. Also called cervical headache.

Abbreviation for chronic fatigue syndrome, a disorder of ongoing, severe tiredness that interferes with a person’s ability to function well, isn’t improved with rest, and isn’t caused by another illness.
A way of testing for food allergy, usually in double-blind experiments in which neither patient nor doctor knows which food is taken in pill form.

A chemical solution applied to the skin to cause it to blister and peel, revealing a new layer of skin; treatment is used to improve the appearance of the skin, reducing lines, wrinkles, age spots, and other problems.
A treatment for low back pain that involves injecting the enzyme chymopapain into a herniated disk.
Using drugs or chemicals to prevent cancer.
The use of chemicals to treat disease; often used to destroy cancer cells.
Abnormal breathing where cycles of deep, labored breathing where cycles of deep, labored breathing are followed by cycles of weak breathing that can result in a total, temporary lack of airflow.
Someone who treats disease by manipulation and adjustment of body structures, often the spine.
A chemical found in green, leafy vegetables thought to help prevent cancer.
Severe iron-deficiency characterized by a yellow-green tinge to the skin.
A substance that causes the gallbladder to squeeze, increasing the discharge of bile.
A hormone that signals the gallbladder to contract, releasing bile, and causes the pancreas to release enzymes used in digestion.
An agent that promotes bile production.
A waxy, fat-like substance produced by the liver and found in all food from animal sources; an essential component of body cells and a precursor of bile acids and some hormones.
A nerve cell that produces acetylcholine.
Arthritis caused by calcium crystals.
A cartilage cell.
A painful condition caused by irritation to or wearing away of the cartilage on the underside of the knee cap; known as runner’s knee.
A thin layer of blood vessels and connective tissue between the white of the eye (sclera) and the retina.
A threadlike structure, found in the nucleus of each cell, that carries almost all of a cell’s genes.
Any condition that lasts a long time or recurs over time.
A disorder of ongoing, severe tiredness that interferes with a person’s ability to function well, isn’t improved with rest, and isn’t caused by another illness.
Any type of kidney disease that lasts longer than three months and impairs kidney function.
Pain that persists after an injury has healed or a disease is over.
Long-term, severe pain that doesn’t spring from an injury or illness, that interferes with daily life, and is often accompanied by other problems, such as depression, irritability, and anxiety.
Severe, frequent, short-lasting migraine-like headache attacks.
A fat globule that ferries triglyceride from the intestine to the liver and fat tissue.
A nearly liquid mass of partly digested food and digestive juices; found in the stomach and intestine.
A group of inflammatory hair disorders that can cause irreversible damage to the follicle that results in permanent hair loss and scarring. Also known as scarring alopecia.
Small, hairlike structures on the surface of some cells.
Part of the eye that produces the aqueous humor (fluid that nourishes the eye) and contains the ciliary muscle, which controls focusing of the lens.
The body’s biological clock that regulates the sleep/wake cycle and other physiological processes.
A circle of arteries at the base of the brain, connecting major brain arteries and supplying blood to all parts of the brain.
A chronic disease of the liver that progressively destroys the liver’s ability to aid in digestion and detoxification.
Abbreviation for creatine kinase, an enzyme found in the heart, brain, and skeletal muscle. Levels of creatine kinase are tested to diagnose certain illnesses.
A migraine headache preceded by visual disturbances; also known as a migraine with aura.
A muscle cramp, usually felt in the calf, caused by poor blood flow to the legs.
A study that tests a therapy in humans, rather than in laboratories or on animals.
An explosive increase in the number of fighter cells released by the immune system to fight a threat in the body.
Medications that dissolve blood clots and restore blood flow through a blocked artery.
A short-lived, extremely painful headache that occurs repeatedly over a period of a few weeks or months and then disappears for months or years.
The process where a liquid, such as blood, comes together to form a soft, semi-solid mass, like a clot.
A narrowed area in the aorta (the main artery that leaves the heart) present from birth.
Part of the ear that converts sound into electrical signals that the brain interprets as a particular sound.
A small electronic device that is implanted in the inner ear to restore some hearing to a deaf person.
A small organic molecule, often made from B vitamins, that helps enzymes function in the body.
A form of therapy that aimed at recognizing and changing negative thoughts and behaviors.
All of the brain mechanisms involved with thinking, reasoning, learning, and remembering.
Problems with memory, language, thinking, or other brain functions, varying from mild to serious difficulty.
The capacity of the brain to use alternative neural pathways or thinking strategies in response to neurological injury from conditions such as Alzheimer’s disease.
Severe abdominal pain caused by spasms in the intestines or in a portion of the kidneys.
A fibrous protein that is the main component of connective tissue in the body.
An enzyme that breaks down collagen.
A system of minor arteries, known as collaterals, that can serve as an alternate blood supply to the heart when a major coronary artery is blocked.
A break at the end of the main bone of the forearm, the radius.
The large intestine; a muscular tube that is 5 to 6 feet long. It compacts and moves solid waste.
A procedure to see inside the colon, using a long, lighted flexible tube mounted with a tiny camera.
A growth on the colon or rectal wall that may develop into cancer.
Surgery that brings one end of the large intestine out through an opening in the abdomen for elimination of stool.
An antibody-rich form of breast milk, produced at the end of pregnancy and for a short time after birth, which strengthens a newborn’s immune system.
Deep unconsciousness where the person is alive but unable to move or respond.
Estrogen combined with progestogen, prescribed to augment a woman’s depleted hormones during menopause.
A condition, usually inherited, in which LDL cholesterol and triglyceride levels are very high.
A migraine headache without any visual symptoms, such as not a blind spot, beforehand. Also called a migraine without aura.
Any disease caused by bacteria, viruses, or other pathogens that is spread from person to person.
Hard, tightly-packed tissue that forms the outer shell of bones. Also called cortical bone or lamellar bone.
Proteins that kill viruses, bacteria, and other microbes directly or flag them for destruction by white blood cells.
Often referred to as CBC. A broad panel of screening tests that examine different parts of the blood and can be used to diagnose anemia, infection, and many other diseases.

A prolonged, intense reaction to bereavement that affects one in 10 people who lose a loved one. Key signs are inability to accept the death; frequent nightmares and intrusive, upsetting memories; detachment from others; constant yearning for the deceased; and excessive loneliness. Sometimes called traumatic or chronic grief.
A migraine where one or more of the symptoms, such as visual problems, linger for at least a day after the headache is gone.
A pharmacy that mixes custom medications for patients and doctors.
The collapse of a bone, most often a bone in the spine (vertebra).
An imaging technique that uses a computer and x-rays passed through the body at different angles to create a detailed, nearly three-dimensional picture of the body.
The start of pregnancy, when an egg is fertilized by a sperm.
Hearing loss caused by a blockage in the middle ear that prevents sound waves from reaching the inner ear.
A rounded knob at the end of a bone.
Cells in the retina that are sensitive to color and light.
An accumulation of mucus or of blood in an organ.

An older term for heart failure, a disorder caused by a decrease in the heart’s ability to pump blood. Congestive heart failure referred specifically to the type of heart failure associated with the accumulation of excess fluid in the lungs or extremities.
A type of vaccine made by attaching an antigen (a substance that the body deems harmful) to a protein. It is often used to immunize babies and young children.
Estrogen medications produced from the urine of pregnant horses.
The clear, thin membrane that covers the inside of the eyelid and the white part of the eyeball.
Swelling or infection of the thin lining on the inside of the eyelid and the white part of the eyeball.
A group of tissues in the body that provide internal support and bind other tissues in the body, including bone, cartilage, tendons, and ligaments.
The process by which the brain transforms newly acquired information into long-term memories.
A rash or skin irritation that results when skin contacts an allergen or irritating substance.
Estrogen and progestogen taken daily by women whose estrogen levels are low, usually due to menopause or a hysterectomy.
A therapy for obstructive sleep apnea in which a machine delivers a continuous stream of air which prevents the collapse of the airway during sleep.
Proteins that help shorten the length of muscle cells, enabling them to contract.
Shortening of a muscle, usually because of disease or lack of use, that limits joint movement.
A fluid injected into the bloodstream or swallowed so that organs will show up on x-rays.
A group of people in a medical study who receive either no treatment or the standard treatment, which is compared against a group who receive the treatment being studied.
Asthma medications taken daily to prevent or control symptoms.
A bruise. An injury that causes swelling, pain, and discoloration but doesn’t break the skin.
Rapid uncontrollable shaking of the body caused by muscles contracting and relaxing repeatedly.
An area of hardened, thickened skin usually caused by friction.
The clear dome that covers the front of the eye.
Pertaining to the arteries that supply blood to the heart.

A test that shows how blood moves through the blood vessels supplying the heart to identify narrowed arteries. It uses x-rays and the injection of a fluid called a contrast agent that can be seen on the x-rays.
Blood vessel that carries oxygen-rich blood to the heart muscle.
Surgery to improve blood flow to the heart by diverting blood around a blocked coronary artery.

A condition in which one or more of the arteries feeding the heart become so narrow in spots that blood flow is impaired or stopped entirely, causing chest pain or a heart attack. Often called heart disease or coronary heart disease.
Surgery to remove fatty plaque that has built up on the walls of a coronary artery.

A commonly used term for coronary artery disease, a condition in which one or more of the arteries feeding the heart become so narrow in spots that blood flow is impaired or stopped entirely, causing chest pain or a heart attack.
Temporary constriction of an artery that supplies blood to the heart, slowing or stopping blood flow.
A ward in a hospital that provides specialized care and monitoring for patients with heart problems.
The large bundle of nerve fibers linking the left and right sides of the brain.
Sponge-like tissue in the penis that fills with blood during sexual arousal, causing an erection.
The egg follicle remnant left behind after an egg has been released during ovulation. The corpus luteum secretes the hormone progesterone to stimulate the growth of the endometrium.
A cylinder of soft tissue surrounding a man’s urethra and running the length of the penis.
One of the muscles that forms frown lines on the forehead.
The middle layer and main structure of the hair shaft, consisting mainly of compact bundles of the protein keratin.
Hard, tightly-packed tissue that forms the outer shell of bones. Also called compact bone.
Steroid medications made to mimic hormones produced naturally by the adrenal glands. They are used to treat a wide range of health problems.
A hormone made in the brain that triggers the body’s fight-or-flight reaction to external threats.
One of a class of stress hormones released during the fight-or-flight stress response.
Abbreviation for cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors, medications that reduce pain and swelling by targeting a particular enzyme known as cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2).

Abbreviation for continuous positive airway pressure, a therapy for obstructive sleep apnea in which a machine delivers a continuous stream of air which prevents the collapse of the airway during sleep.
Abbreviation for cardiopulmonary resuscitation, a combination of chest compressions and mouth-to-mouth breathing that keep oxygenated blood circulating to the brain and tissues.
Inflammation and damage to blood vessels supplying blood to the head and neck. Also called giant cell arteritis.
Intense, often irrepressible urge for something; often a symptom of dependence on drugs, alcohol or addiction.
A protein made by the liver. High amounts of C-reactive protein may indicate that arteries are clogged (atherosclerosis).
An enzyme that leaks into the bloodstream in high amounts if a muscle is damaged. Can be used to detect heart attack or muscle damage from other diseases.
A waste product created by muscle metabolism. Doctors sometimes test creatinine levels to examine kidney function.
A blood or urine test that helps doctors determine if the kidneys are working properly.
Grating, grinding, or popping sound or feeling made when a joint is moved.
A rare, untreatable, rapid form of dementia that is fatal.
A chronic disease that causes swelling of the digestive tract, pain, and diarrhea.
The part of the tooth that is visible above the gum line. Also a restoration that covers the crown of the tooth.
Use of extreme cold to freeze and destroy diseased tissue.
Abbreviation for C-reactive protein, a protein made by the liver. High amounts of C-reactive protein may indicate that arteries are clogged (atherosclerosis).
Part of the eye that changes shape so that the eye can focus on objects at different distances.
Computerized x-rays that provide detailed views of the body and brain. Also known as a computed tomography (CT) scan.
Use of a CT scan and an injectable dye to show arteries and blood vessels in detail.
The pinching of a nerve at the elbow, causing numbness in the pinkie and ring fingers and part of the hand.
An indentation in the optic disc that grows abnormally large with glaucoma.
Using a spoon-shaped instrument to remove diseased tissue or sample tissue.
A disorder caused by high levels of the stress-hormone cortisol resulting in damage to the body, including abdominal obesity, rounded red face, and other symptoms.
The outermost, single-cell layer of the hair shaft.
A condition in which skin turns blue due to a lack of oxygen in the blood, often because of heart failure or lung disease.
A chemical in the body that widens blood vessels in the penis. This increases blood flow to the penis, causing an erection.
Use of estrogen and progestogen for 10–14 days of the month to relieve symptoms of menopause.
An enzyme that helps blood cells known as platelets stick to each other, a key step in the formation of a blood clot.
An abnormal growth in the body that is noncancerous.
An eye condition in which the retina (the macula) becomes swollen with fluid.
Proteins in the body that act as messengers between immune system cells.
Drug-induced hair loss that occurs some weeks after the start of chemotherapy; hair grows back after cessation of treatment.
A type of dopamine receptor (see neurotransmitter receptors) that seems to be particularly important in addiction.
A substance found in soybeans.
A guide to the amount of nutrients in a given food; Daily values are given in percentages based on a 2,000-calorie-per-day diet.
A mild and common condition that is characterized by an itchy, flaky scalp and that may extend to the ears, face, and chest. Also known as seborrheic dermatitis.
Painful swelling of the tendons at the wrist that move the thumb.
Weakness or a loss of physical strength.
A unit of measurement for the loudness of a sound. The highest decibels indicate the loudest sounds.
Memory for facts or events (episodic memory); also called explicit memory.
An herbal product or tea made by boiling a plant in water.
Type of medication used to relieve nasal congestion.
Stage of sleep where the brain is less responsive to outside stimuli.
A dangerous condition in which blood clots form in veins deep in the body, usually the legs. They may break off and block blood flow in the lungs, seriously damaging organs or causing death.
Coping strategies a person adopts to make it easier to operate in the world.
The delivery of an electric shock to the heart to stop an abnormal rhythm and restore a normal heartbeat.
A device that delivers an electric shock to the heart to restore normal rhythm. Used to treat cardiac arrest and other dangerous heart rhythm problems.
Any disease in which the organs or tissues in the body are damaged progressively over time.
Normal, and sometimes painful, deteriorations in the disks of the spine that occur with age.
Arthritis that occurs when the cartilage in joints breaks down over time; also called osteoarthritis.
Arthritis of the spine that worsens over time; often caused by aging.
A pattern of falling asleep and waking up later than wanted that tends to worsen progressively over time.
Sudden, severe confusion that occurs because of a mental or physical illness.
Slow brain activity that occurs when a person is in deep sleep.
A false or irrational belief held by a person despite evidence to the contrary.
A loss of brain function that worsens over time and affects memory, thinking, behavior, and language.
Loss of brain function, common among former boxers, caused by repeated blows to the head.
The process by which bacteria destroy tooth enamel.
A substance that soothes irritated tissues and mucous membranes.
The parts of a nerve cell that receive signals from other nerve cells.
Spidery-looking immune system cells that help protect the body from harmful substances.

A defense mechanism characterized by the inability to recognize or admit that addiction is the cause of problems, rather than a solution or mere byproduct. Denial can also refer to the refusal to accept an upsetting reality, such as a serious illness or death or the feelings that follow either.
A metal post inserted into the alveolar bone to support an artificial tooth or other prosthesis.
The layer of hardened tooth tissue under the enamel and around the pulp.
The substance found in the nucleus of cells that contains the genetic instructions for that living organism.
A structure situated at the base of the hair follicle that contains nerves and blood vessels that fuel the cellular processes of the developing hair shaft.
A rare disease in which the muscles become weak and stiff and a skin rash appears.
The middle layer of skin that contains most of the skin’s structures, like collagen, nerves, glands, and hair follicles.
An extract made of dried animal thyroid glands.
The process of removing harmful, or toxic, substances from a person’s body.
The sudden, strong need to urinate due to spasms in bladder muscles. Also called urge incontinence.
The layer of muscle in the bladder wall that squeezes urine out of the bladder.
The softening of an erection.
A disease in which the body does not properly produce or use insulin, resulting in abnormally high levels of sugar (glucose) in the blood.
A complication of diabetes in which substances called ketones build up in the blood to dangerously high levels.
A complication of diabetes that occurs when the small blood vessels in the retina are damaged. It can impair vision or even lead to blindness.
The dome-shaped sheet of muscle at the base of the lungs that helps move air in and out of the lungs.
The relaxation phase of the normal heart cycle.
The bottom number of a blood pressure reading, such as 134/78. It represents the pressure in the arteries when the heart relaxes between beats.

The inability of the heart to relax properly between beats (diastole), making it difficult for the ventricles to fill completely with blood from the atria. This can occur when the heart muscle bulks up due to overwork or other causes or when the heart muscle stiffens and loses it flexibility.
Use of high-frequency electric currents to heat deep muscle and joint tissue as a form of physical therapy.
The part of plant foods the body can’t digest or absorb. Also called roughage.
The recommended amount of vitamins and minerals individuals should consume per day.
Vitamins, minerals, herbs, and other substances taken in hopes of improving health.
The series of hollow organs, including the mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine (colon), rectum, and anus, which break down and digest food and expel waste.
A finger or toe.
An exam in which a doctor inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to check for abnormalities.
A drug that increases the strength of heart muscle contractions.
A form of the hormone testosterone that spurs the prostate gland to enlarge (benign prostatic hyperplasia).
To widen or enlarge.
The immediate transfer of an infectious agent from a reservoir to a susceptible host by direct contact or droplet spread.
A rare form of lupus that causes a rash or scarring of skin.
One of the small, shock-absorbing cushions found between the bones that make up the spinal column (vertebrae).
The surgical removal of part of a disk (a small, shock absorbing cushion located between the bones of the spinal column).
Swelling of one or more of the pillow-like disks located between the bones of the spinal column.
The movement of a bone from its normal position.
A substance found in cruciferous vegetables, like cabbage, Brussels sprouts, and broccoli, which may play a role in cancer prevention.

A drug that eases the heart's workload and decreases the buildup of fluid in the lungs and other parts of the body by promoting the excretion of water and salts. Diuretics (also called water pills) are used to treat high blood pressure, heart failure, and some congenital heart defects.
The bulging out of small pouches or sacs of tissue from the colon wall.
A small pouch or sac of tissue that bulges out of the colon wall. The plural form is diverticula.
A substance found in citrus fruits.
An abbreviation for deoxyribonucleic acid, the substance in cells that contains the genetic instructions that direct their function.
Commonly used abbreviation for do-not-resuscitate order, a legal document that tells health professionals not to revive a person if his or her heart or breathing stops.

When the genetic trait carried by one allele of a gene pair eclipses the trait carried by another; for example, when a gene carries alleles for two different eye colors, the dominant eye color gene determines the person’s eye color.do-not-resuscitate order: A legal document that tells health professionals not to revive a person if his or her heart or breathing stops. Commonly referred to as a DNR.
A chemical messenger (neurotransmitter) that affects movement and thought processes.
A test that uses sound waves to measure how fast blood is flowing through blood vessels.
Near the back of the body or an organ.
A rounded or curved back caused by spinal fractures from osteoporosis. Commonly called dowager’s hump.

A medical study in which the researchers and participants don’t know which group is receiving the medication or treatment being studied and which is getting a placebo (fake, inactive version of the medication).
An x-ray test done to check for colon cancer or other bowel diseases.
A rounded or curved back (resembling a hump) caused by spinal fractures from osteoporosis.
Medication used to treat high blood pressure or an enlarged prostate gland.
Inflammation of the sac surrounding the heart (pericardium).
Abbreviation for dietary reference intake, the recommended amount of vitamins and minerals individuals should consume per day.
Tiny yellow deposits in the retina of the eye.
Stinging, burning, or irritation that occurs when the eye doesn’t produce enough moisture.
A small device that helps a person breathe in dry medication so it reaches the lungs.
An x-ray test used to measure bone density and check for osteoporosis.
A test to measure bone density, usually in the spine or the hip.
A tube or vessel in the body which carries the secretion of a gland; Secretion examples are tears, breast milk, etc.
Inflammation of the duodenum, which is the upper part of the small intestine.
The upper part of the small intestine.
A tool that uses sound waves to reveal blood flow problems.
A condition that deforms the hand, causing fingers to curl toward the palm.
A thin protective membrane covering the brain and spinal cord.
A legal document in which an individual appoints another person to make medical, financial, or other decisions when the individual becomes unable to make those decisions.

A speech disability caused by an injury to the brain centers controlling the face, mouth, neck, or throat. People with dysarthria may be able to understand speech and form the right words in their mind but cannot articulate them.
Painful sexual intercourse.
Pain or discomfort in the upper abdomen; upset stomach or indigestion.
Difficulty chewing and swallowing food. Dysphagia is extremely common after a stroke.
Abnormal changes in cells of a tissue. The cells aren’t cancerous, but they can sometimes progress to cancer.
Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath.
A disorder in which muscles twitch, causing uncontrollable twisting movements.
A tube leading from the eardrum to the outer ear.
A thin membrane separating the ear canal and middle ear.
A substance that lubricates the inner ear and helps protect it from dirt, damage, and infections.
Abbreviation for electron-beam computed tomography, a high-speed imaging technology use to evaluate the heart and measure calcium deposits in arteries.
When muscles move joints by lengthening. Also known as cerumen.
An abbreviation for electrocardiogram, a test that measures the electrical activity of the heart and detects heart problems.
A diagnostic tool that uses high-frequency sound waves (ultrasound) to make images of the heart's size, structure and motion.
A serious condition related to high blood pressure that can threaten the life of a pregnant woman and her fetus.
Pregnancy in which a fertilized egg implants in an abnormal location outside the uterus, usually in the fallopian tubes. Ending the pregnancy is necessary.
When an eyelid, usually the lower one, flips outward so that the inner surface is exposed.
A condition in which areas of the skin are dry, itchy, red, and cracked. Also known as atopic dermatitis.
Commonly used abbreviation for erectile dysfunction, the inability to get or maintain an erection sufficient for intercourse.
Swelling caused by abnormal accumulation of fluid in tissues.
Abbreviation for electroencephalogram, a test that measures the electrical activity of the brain and detects problems.
An abnormal buildup of fluid in a joint or tissue.
A nerve responsible transmitting sound and information about balance to the brain. Also called the auditory nerve.
A sudden discharge of a fluid from a duct; often used to describe the expulsion of seminal fluid from the urethra of the penis during orgasm.
The percent of blood pumped out of the left ventricle with each heartbeat. A normal ejection fraction is in the range of 55% to 70%.
An abbreviation for electrocardiogram, a test that measures the electrical activity of the heart and detects heart problems.
A flexible, stretchy protein found in skin and connective tissue.
A test that measures the electrical activity of the heart and detects heart problems.
A test that measures the electrical activity of the brain and detects problems.
A permanent hair removal technique that destroys follicles one at a time with a hair-thin needle inserted into the base of the follicle.
Minerals in the body that are electrically charged and play an important role in body processes, such as regulating fluid levels in the body. Examples include calcium and sodium.
A test that checks the health of muscles and the nerves that control them.
A high-speed imaging technology use to evaluate the heart and measure calcium deposits in arteries. Sometimes referred to as EBCT.
A procedure used to provoke known or suspected arrhythmias.
A way of diagnosing food allergies in which suspected foods are removed from the diet one at a time until the food causing a problem is found.
A chemical found in certain plants, such as raspberries and strawberries, that might help protect against cancer.

A type of stroke that occurs when a blood clot that has formed elsewhere in the body breaks off and travels through the bloodstream until it blocks an artery that normally supplies blood to the brain.
Blockage of a blood vessel by a clot (an embolus) that has traveled from another part of the body.
A blood clot or particle that forms in one part of the body then moves through the bloodstream and lodges in a blood vessel elsewhere, blocking blood flow.
Any drug or other substance used to cause vomiting.
Abbreviation for electromyography—a test that checks the health of muscles and the nerves that control them.
The discharge or release of a substance, usually a fluid.
Herbs that stimulate menstrual blood flow.
The hard outside layer of tooth material.
A severe and sometimes deadly inflammation of the brain that can be caused by a number of different viruses.
A multistage process by which sensation, perception, or thought is transformed into neural representations that can be stored in memory.
Surgical removal of plaque or blood clots in an artery.
Continually present among people in a geographic region.
An inflammation of the heart lining or valves, usually caused by bacterial infection.
The inner layer of the wall of the heart.
Painkilling substances made by the body.
The lining of the uterus.
Substances in the body that reduce pain and create a feeling of well-being.
A thin, flexible tube equipped with a light and camera that is used to see inside an organ or body cavity.
Inserting a flexible tube equipped with a light and camera into the body to see inside a body cavity or organ.
Proteins that cause blood vessels to narrow and blood pressure to rise.
Chemicals in the body that cause blood vessels to expand or relax, lowering blood pressure. Often referred to as EDRF.
Complete, or nearly complete, kidney failure. Dialysis or a transplant is needed for survival.
A chemical produced in the brain that reduces pain.
Part of the nervous system that controls the gastrointestinal system.
Disease affecting the intestinal tract.
A place where a ligament, tendon, or muscle attaches to bone.
An eyelid, usually the lower lid, which folds inward so that the eyelashes rub against and irritate the surface of the eye.
A substance that speeds up another chemical reaction. For example, digestive enzymes help speed up the digestion of food.
White blood cells that play an important role in allergic reactions.
The outer layer of the wall of the heart.
Pain and swelling in the tendons in the elbow, usually because of overuse.
The occurrence of more cases of disease than expected within a population in a geographic area over a set period of time.
An investigation of the links between certain behaviors or risk factors and the occurrence of disease or good health in a population.
The outermost layer of skin.
The space between the spinal cord and the bones of the spinal column where painkillers are injected.
A chemical that narrows blood vessels, increases heart rate, and helps trigger the fight-or-flight response to danger. Also called adrenaline.
A device used to inject a dose of medication (epinephrine) when a severe allergic reaction occurs.
Cells which line organs and structures in the body, protecting or enclosing them.
A layer of cells which lines organs and structures in the body, protecting or enclosing them.
The inability to get or maintain an erection sufficient for intercourse. Sometimes referred to as ED.
A group of muscles and tendons in the back.
Designing and arranging work objects so that the user is comfortable, efficient, and less likely to be injured.
Substances derived from or made from a fungus; often used to treat headache.
The act of bringing up air from the stomach through the mouth with a characteristic sound. Commonly known as belching.
Redness of the skin because of widening of capillaries just below the surface of the skin.
Painful, red lumps beneath the skin; associated with Crohn's disease.
A test involving red blood cells; used to check for different infections, inflammations, and cancers.
A hormone that controls red blood cell production.
A test to measure the pressure inside the lower part of the esophagus.
Irritation and swelling of the esophagus.
The tube that carries food and liquids from the mouth to the stomach.
Two fatty acids, omega-3 and omega-6, that the body needs for good health but can’t make so they must come from foods and supplements.
High blood pressure with no known cause; also called primary hypertension.
Artificially made hormones used to manage menopausal symptoms.
A person who specializes in non-medical skin care and beauty treatments.
The primary form of the sex hormone estrogen produced by women.
The main sex hormone in women.
A site on the surface of some cells to which estrogen molecules attach.
Use of medications containing the sex hormone estrogen by women to replace naturally-occurring estrogen lost during menopause.
A medication used to treat bone loss due to Paget's disease.
A tube connecting the middle ear and the back of the nose that lets air into the middle ear.
Having a thyroid gland that works properly.
A chemical that forwards a message from one neuron to another.
A brain chemical that damages neurons.
The component of thinking that organizes, plans, decides, and inhibits inappropriate impulses.
A structured program of physical activity that helps an individual become physically fit.

The use of a treadmill, stationary bicycle, or other exercise machine while hooked up to heart-monitoring equipment. The test is used to determine if the heart's blood supply is sufficient and if the rhythm remains normal when the heart is stressed.
A protrusion or bulging of the eye that occurs with Graves’ eye disease. Tissues behind the eye swell, forcing the eyeball forward. Also called proptosis.
Abnormal bony growths in the ear caused by swimming regularly in cold water. Sometimes called surfer's ear.
A research technique for learning about people’s activity patterns and psychological processes that involves paging them at random times to obtain brief reports.

A common phenomenon whereby people jump to a different expression of addiction. For example, people with heroin addiction might transition to alcohol addiction. Hopping is especially common during the recovery process.
The specific way in which a person manifests addiction, for example, through the use of cocaine, or compulsive gambling.
To straighten out a joint (for example, extending the arms overhead).
An infection or irritation of the outer ear, ear canal, or both. Also called swimmer’s ear.
A surgical technique to remove a cataract from the eye.
A product made from substances that are drawn out of a plant or herb.
Six paired muscles that direct the eyes’ circular, side-to-side, and up-and-down movements.
An outside factor that has an effect on a person’s environment or well-being.
Paired joints that link a vertebra to its neighboring vertebrae. They allow the spine to move as a unit.
Surgical destruction of certain nerves and nerve roots to relieve pain.
Test results that show that a disease or substance isn’t present, even though it is.
An inherited disorder in which the liver overproduces very low-density lipoprotein, causing high levels of cholesterol or triglycerides, or both.
