An inherited disorder in which the liver cannot properly remove low-density lipoprotein particles from the blood, causing a very high cholesterol level.

A laboratory test to determine the relative levels of high-density lipoprotein, low-density lipoprotein, and total cholesterol in the blood. Also referred to as a lipoprotein analysis, full lipid profile, or cholesterol profile.
A blood test that determines the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood after an overnight fast of at least eight hours.
One of two main types of skeletal muscle fibers. Fast-twitch fibers are recruited most heavily when bursts of power are needed, as in sprinting. See also slow-twitch fiber.
One of the three major nutrients, along with carbohydrates and proteins.
A lack of energy. A decrease over time in the ability to perform a physical or mental task.
Components of fats that can be used for energy by cells.
The first stage of atherosclerosis, a build-up of fatty materials in the wall of a blood vessel.
Feverish; having a high body temperature.
A mass of dry, hard stool that gets lodged in the rectum.
A test that checks for colorectal cancer by detecting blood in the stool.
Thigh bone.
A protein that captures and stores iron.
A collection of birth defects resulting from exposure of the fetus to alcohol during pregnancy.
A substance found in plant foods that the body can’t digest.
Rapid and uncoordinated contractions of heart muscle fibers. When this occurs, the heart can't properly contract or pump blood.
A stringy protein that is the primary component of a blood clot.
A protein that helps stop bleeding by aiding in forming blood clots.
A tumor that is not cancer; usually found in the breast.
A cell that helps form the collagen and elastic fibers of connective tissue.
A tumor that is not cancer, which is found in the uterus.
A condition causing pain and tender spots throughout the body.
A buildup of fat on the inside of a blood vessel that interferes with blood flow.
The calf bone.
A procedure to treat glaucoma in which a surgeon creates a drainage hole in the eye to relieve pressure.
A medication for treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlargement of the prostate gland).
An area where two bones meet that is fixed, or doesn’t move.
Soft, not erect.
Reappearance or worsening of symptoms.
A condition in which the arch is flat all the time or flattens when bearing weight.
Excess gas in the stomach or intestines that is expelled from the anus.
Gas expelled through the anus.
Chemicals found in fruits, vegetables, wine, and tea that may protect cells from damage and have health benefits.
Bend a joint (for example, flexing the knees).
A component of physical fitness that refers to the range of motion available at a joint.
Changes that occur in the body, such as rapid breathing and heartbeat, when a person is confronted with a perceived physical or emotional threat. Also called the stress response.
Tiny spots or lines that appear in a person’s field of vision when the jelly-like fluid of the eye breaks down with age. They are usually harmless, but can signal serious eye problems.

A term coined by positive psychology pioneer Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi to describe an effortless, active state of being during which one loses awareness of time, self, and distractions. Flow hinges on balancing the size of a challenge and the level of skill a person brings to it.
A test that uses special dye and a camera to examine blood flow in the retina.
A mineral that protects teeth from decay and cavities.
A test that gives moving images of the inside of the body; could be likened to an x-ray movie.
Lipid-laden cells, named for their foamy appearance under the microscope. As foam cells build up on the inside of blood vessel walls, they form a plaque that can block blood flow.
Damage to a specific nerve, causing pain or numbness.
Peaceful, relaxing words or phrases used during stress relief exercises.
A group of cells that form a small sac.
A hormone released by the pituitary gland that stimulates the production of eggs in women and sperm in men.
A small bundle that includes one to four follicles, oil glands, a tiny muscle, and other tissue.
Transplantation of follicular units, which mimic natural hair growth.
An inflammation of the hair follicle.
Sensitivities to certain foods that can cause symptoms ranging from the mild (like hives) to the life threatening (such as anaphylaxis).
Cosmetic surgery to minimize creases on the forehead and between the eyebrows, and to lift sagging eyebrows.
A small dimple in the middle of the retina that provides sharp central vision.
A break in a bone.
An algorithm for estimating the probability of breaking a bone because of low bone mass over a period of 10 years.
Part of a disk in the back that has broken off from the main portion of the disk.
An unstable molecule in the body that plays a role in aging and can damage tissue; antioxidants help prevent free radical damage.
The pitch of a sound; measured by the speed at which sound waves vibrate.
How much amplification a hearing aid produces in both high and low frequencies.
The amplification that a hearing aid produces across different sound frequencies.
Part of the brain that plays a role in determining consequences and choosing behaviors.
A brain disorder that can cause dementia, aphasia, neurotic behavior, and gradual changes in personality and emotional control.
Inflammation of various tissues of the shoulder, along with growth of abnormal bands of tissue that cause the shoulder to become so stiff that movement is severely limited.
A simple sugar found in corn syrup, honey, and many sweet fruits.
Abbreviation for follicle-stimulating hormone, a hormone released by the pituitary gland that stimulates the production of eggs in women and sperm in men.
Gut problems that aren’t caused by an infection or structural problem with the gastrointestinal system.
Recognition of the need to urinate but being unable to get to the bathroom in time due to mental or physical problems, such as limited mobility.
Surgery that restructures the stomach to prevent acid reflux.
Imaging test that provides multi-dimensional pictures of the back of the eyeball.
Organisms and microorganisms, such as yeasts and molds, that can live as a parasite on plants and animals.
A hearing aid’s power, measured in the number of decibels that it can add to sound.
The cycle that the feet and legs make when walking, beginning when one heel hits the ground and ending when the same heel hits the ground again.
A substance that promotes breast milk production.
A chemical messenger in the brain that may help decrease anxiety and promote slow-wave sleep. Often referred to as GABA.
An abnormal but harmless mass of tissue, usually nerve cells.
A harmless sac of fluid on top of a joint or tendon, usually on the wrist or back of the hand.
Death of tissue in part of the body because blood has stopped flowing there.
Relating to the stomach.
Inflammation of the lining of the stomach.
A condition in which food and acid flow back into the esophagus from the stomach, causing heartburn.
Relating to all or some of the organs of the digestive tract, from the mouth to the anus.
The digestive tract.
Structures on chromosomes that are passed from parent to child. The basic unit of material that passes traits from parent to child.
Correction of a genetic defect by replacing an abnormal gene with a normal gene.
A copy of a brand-name drug whose patent has expired. These drugs are less expensive than brand-name drugs.
Referring to inherited characteristics or genes.
An antioxidant chemical found in certain plants, like soybeans.
Abbreviation for gastroesophageal reflux disease, a condition in which food and acid flow back into the esophagus from the stomach, causing heartburn.
A trained medical professional who helps families who are caring for older adults.
A physician who specializes in the care of older patients.
A form of diabetes that appears during pregnancy.
Abbreviation for glomerular filtration rate, the rate at which the kidneys filter excess water and other wastes. A test by the same name is used to determine how well the kidneys are functioning.
Inflammation and damage to blood vessels that supply the head and neck.
Another term for gums: a form of oral tissue that covers the roots of teeth and surrounding bone.
Inflammation of the gums.
Any organ or tissue that secretes fluids, such as hormones, for use elsewhere in the body or as waste.
The head of the penis.
A condition in which the pressure inside the eye is too high, causing eye damage.
In men with prostate cancer, the Gleason score provides a rough estimate of how fast the cancer is growing.
A shoulder joint that connects the ball of the humerus to the glenoid.
The socket of the scapula that connects to the humerus at the shoulder.
The rate at which the kidneys filter excess water and other wastes. A test by the same name is used to determine how well the kidneys are functioning.
Tiny clusters of capillaries in the kidneys that filter waste products from the blood.
A hormone produced in the pancreas that raises blood sugar levels.
Steroid hormones released by the adrenal gland when there seems to be a threat, and the stress response is triggered.
A simple sugar that is the body’s main source of energy.
Blood sugar levels that are higher than normal, but not yet high enough for a diagnosis of diabetes.
A chemical messenger in the brain that may play a role in mood disorders and schizophrenia.
A protein found in beta cells, the cells that create insulin.
A ranking of foods according to how quickly and how much they raise blood sugar.
A ranking of how much a typical serving of a particular food will raise blood sugar.
The body’s fuel reserves. This substance, stored primarily in the liver and muscles, is later converted into glucose to provide cells with energy.
The product formed by the attachment of glucose (blood sugar) to hemoglobin (the oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells). Usually referred to as hemoglobin A1c, or HbA1c.
Abbreviation for gonadotropin-releasing hormone, a hormone responsible for the release of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone from the pituitary gland.
Drugs used to treat prostate cancer by blocking the release of luteinizing hormone that do not cause a temporary surge in testosterone.
Cells that produce mucus that line the gastrointestinal tract and lungs.
An enlarged thyroid gland that creates a lump in the neck.
A hormone responsible for the release of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone from the pituitary gland.
A test used to detect glaucoma that examines the area where fluid drains out of the eye.
A form of arthritis that occurs when uric acid builds up in the joints; The big toe, knee, and ankle joints are most often affected.
Transplanting tissue from one part of the body to another.
A metric unit of weight equivalent to one-thousandth of a kilogram.

An autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to produce too much thyroid hormone. It is usually accompanied by an enlarged thyroid gland and swollen, bulging, red eyes that appear to stare, as well as occasional double vision and vision loss.
A fracture in a young, soft bone in which the bone bends and breaks only on the outer edge of the bend.
A broad range of reactions to bereavement, including sadness, tears, shock, confusion, and anger, among others.
A substance produced by the body to stimulate tissue growth.
The area of sexually sensitive tissue located on the roof of the vagina just inside the opening. Also known as the Grafenberg spot.
A legal process of appointing a person to make decisions about important matters (such as health and finances) for someone who is unfit to make those decisions on his or her own.
The esophagus.
Diseases including gingivitis and periodontitis that attack the gum tissue and the structures supporting the teeth. Also called periodontal disease.
A form of oral tissue that covers the roots of teeth and surrounding bone. Also called the gingiva.
The root of the hair shaft.
Cells in the ear that transmit sound messages to the brain and play a vital role in hearing.
The portion of hair that extends beyond the surface of the skin. It contains three layers: the cuticle, cortex, and medulla (not always present).
A perception of something that is not really there.
A sometimes painful condition in which the toe curls up and under (resembling a hammer).
Feelings of contentment or joy; the overall experience of pleasure and meaning in life.

An individual's baseline level of happiness, determined largely by genetics, around which moods fluctuate. After reacting to positive or negative life changes, people tend to return to their happiness set-points.

A treatment strategy aimed at minimizing the harm associated with an object of addiction. This strategic approach helps people learn how to limit the degree to which they use their object of addiction, or limit the risks associated with their use, but they do not necessarily stop altogether.
A disease in which the body’s immune system prevents the thyroid gland from producing enough thyroid hormone.

A commonly used term for allergic rhinitis—seasonal or year-round allergic condition marked by sneezing, runny nose, and congestion. The most common type of allergy, it is caused by an IgE-mediated immune response to inhaled airborne allergens.

Abbreviation for hemoglobin A1c, the product formed by the attachment of glucose (blood sugar) to hemoglobin (a protein in red blood cells). A test for HbA1c is a useful measure of blood sugar control.
Abbreviation for high-density lipoprotein, the so-called good cholesterol. This lipoprotein (a substance made up of fats and protein) is believed to remove cholesterol from the arteries.
A legal form allowing a person to appoint someone else to make their medical decisions. Also known as a durable power of attorney for health care.
An electronic device worn in or behind the ear by people with hearing problems that makes sounds louder.

The common term for a myocardial infarction. It refers to the damage that occurs when blood flow to part of the heart is blocked or drastically restricted. The blockage usually stems from the rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque.
The difficulty or inability of the electrical signal that triggers a heart contraction to pass through the atrioventricular node.
The inability of the heart to pump enough blood to meet the needs of the body's organs.
An extra or unusual sound heard during the heartbeat. A murmur may or may not be a sign of a problem in the heart.
The number of times the heart contracts in a minute, normally 60–100 times.
A burning pain in the chest or throat, caused when stomach acid backs up into the esophagus.
Bony bumps found on the finger joints in some people with osteoarthritis.
Devoted to pleasure.
The human tendency to adapt to new circumstances and eventually consider them to be normal, so the emotional effects (negative or positive) generated by a change fade over time.
An abnormal growth of bone or calcium on the heel bone.
Bacteria that damages the lining the stomach. It is to blame for most ulcers and stomach inflammation. Often called H. pylori.
Cells that help fight disease by activating and directing other immune system cells.
The vomiting of bright red blood, indicating bleeding in the upper digestive tract.
Blood that leaks out of blood vessels and collects in the body.
Blood in the urine.
Poor vision or blindness in half of the visual field, affecting one or both eyes.
Muscle weakness on one side of the body.
Paralysis on one side of the body.
A genetic condition in which the body absorbs and stores too much iron.
The use of a machine to remove wastes and impurities from the blood when the kidneys are not working properly.
The oxygen-carrying substance that gives red blood cells their color.
Coughing up or spitting up blood from the lungs.
Bleeding from a damaged blood vessel.
A type of stroke that occurs when a blood vessel leaks or bursts inside the brain, cutting off the supply of oxygen and nutrition to that part of the brain.
Abbreviation for high-efficiency particulate air, a type of highly efficient air filter.
A drug that prevents blood from clotting.
Protection occurring when so many people in a region are immune to an infectious disease that it can’t spread to others.
When part of a spinal disk bulges out of a tear or weak spot in the disk’s tough outer shell. Also known as prolapsed disk.
A painful blistering skin rash caused by the chicken pox virus; also known as shingles.
The measurement of a sound’s frequency.
When part of the stomach pushes upward into the chest through an abnormal opening in the diaphragm.
When blood flowing through arteries pushes on artery walls with abnormally high force over a sustained period of time. Also called hypertension.
So-called good cholesterol. This lipoprotein (a substance made of fat and protein) removes cholesterol from arteries.
A treatment that destroys tumors with heat generated by ultrasound energy.
Part of the brain that plays an important role in processing long-term memories.
Excessive facial or body hair in women.
A substance released by the immune system when it is exposed to an allergen. Histamines cause many allergy symptoms.

Abbreviation for human immunodeficiency virus, the virus that leads to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). HIV damages immune cells so that they are no longer able to fight off other infections.
An itchy rash of usually short duration. Also known as urticaria.
Abbreviation for human leukocyte antigen, a protein found on the surface of white blood cells that helps the body recognize and fight foreign substances.
A small machine worn for a day or more to continuously record the heart’s electrical activity. Holter monitors are used to help diagnose heart rhythm problems.
The body’s ability to keep blood pressure, temperature, water levels, oxygen levels, and more set at the right levels for cells to survive.
An amino acid formed as part of the normal breakdown of protein.
A rare genetic disease that causes blood levels of homocysteine to rise too high.
Use of medications to boost levels of hormones that decrease with age.
Powerful chemicals that affect many processes in the body, including sexual function, mood, and growth.
A person or other living organism that can be infected by a virus or other pathogen under natural conditions.
A sudden, intense, hot feeling in the face or upper part of the body, along with rapid heartbeat, sweating, and flushing. A symptom of menopause.
Abbreviation for hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, a system that controls many hormonal activities in the body, including the stress response.
Usually abbreviated as HIV, the virus that leads to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). HIV damages immune cells so that they are no longer able to fight off other infections.
A protein found on the surface of white blood cells that helps the body recognize and fight foreign substances.
An agent used in moisturizers; binds water to the skin to promote hydration.
Immunity from infection and disease that comes from the release of antibodies in the blood.
An inherited disorder characterized by involuntary jerky movements and dementia.
A hydrating sugar secreted by cells.
A test used to diagnose gastrointestinal problems; it measures the amount of hydrogen in the breath, which rise when food isn’t being absorbed properly.
The addition of hydrogen to a compound. Hydrogenation is used to solidify liquid vegetable oils. The process creates trans fats, which are harmful to the heart and blood vessels.
A hard substance that is a major component of bones and teeth.
The theory that modern cleanliness means children are not exposed to as many germs at an early age, which results in a more allergies.
Overproduction of the hormone aldosterone, which causes the kidneys to retain sodium and water, often leading to high blood pressure.
An increased sensitivity to pain.
High levels of cholesterol in the blood.
An abnormally high amount of sugar in the blood.
High levels of insulin in the bloodstream.
High levels of blood lipids (fats and waxes such as cholesterol).
Difficulty seeing objects that are nearby; farsightedness.
Overproduction by the thyroid glands of parathyroid hormone.
Increased production of cells in a normal tissue or organ; may be harmless or a sign of precancerous changes.
Noncancerous growths commonly found in the colon and rectum.

The medical term for high blood pressure. Hypertension is a major risk factor for stroke, especially hemorrhagic and lacunar strokes, because it puts excess stress on the walls of blood vessels and damages their delicate inner lining.
A stroke in which there is bleeding in the cerebellum because high blood pressure has weakened arteries in the brain.
A stroke in which high blood pressure causes a blood vessel deep in the brain to rupture.
A condition in which the thyroid gland makes too much thyroid hormone.
High levels of triglycerides in the blood. A normal triglyceride level is less than 150 mg/dL.
Abnormally high levels of uric acid in the blood.
Vivid dream-like sounds or images that occur while on the verge of falling asleep.
A diagram that summarizes the stages of sleep recorded in a sleep laboratory.
An agent that promotes and aids sleep.
A condition in which blood sugar drops to an abnormally low level.
Extremely low levels of testosterone in circulation.
A mild form of mania, in which a person has lots of energy, talks faster than normal, has racing thoughts, and elevated mood.
Breathing that is more shallow and slow than normal.
The medical term for low blood pressure.
A system that controls many hormonal activities in the body, including the stress response. Often called the HPA axis.
A small area in the brain that produces hormones that control body temperature, hunger, moods, the stress response, and other key functions.
A disease in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone.
When all or part of the body doesn’t get enough oxygen.
An operation to remove a woman’s uterus.
Complications or poor effects caused by medical treatment.
Abbreviation for inflammatory bowel disease, a general term for two disorders—ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease—that cause the intestines to become swollen and inflamed.

Abbreviation for implantable cardioverter defibrillator, a device implanted in the chest and connected to the heart that delivers a shock to stop a potentially deadly rhythm and restore a normal (sinus) rhythm.
Stabbing, very intense headaches that come on suddenly and are very brief.
A condition or disease of unknown origin.
Abbreviation for immunoglobulin E, the substance responsible for most allergic reactions.
The final section of the small intestine.
Two muscles, running from the end of the spine to the thighbone, that are responsible for lifting the knee.
A category of allergic reaction, triggered by specific allergens and involving IgE. The majority of allergic reactions to pollens, pets, dust, mold, food, and insect venom are of this type.
To restrict the movement of a limb or other part of the body to help in healing.
The body’s ability to resist infection and disease.
Injection of harmless bacteria or viruses to spur the body to produce antibodies so it can resist a particular disease.
Substances made by the immune system that attack foreign substances. Also known as antibodies.
The substance responsible for most allergic reactions.
A part of the body—such as the eye or ovaries—where the immune system isn’t able to function because it may damage the tissue there.
Medication that stifles the body's immune response; often given after an organ transplant to prevent rejection of the new organ.
Treating disease by enhancing or suppressing the body’s immune system.
Something firmly fixed into place, such as a wisdom tooth.
A mass of hardened feces blocking the rectum or colon.
Blood sugar levels that are higher than normal but not yet diabetic. This term is used when the high blood sugar levels are found with a fasting plasma glucose test.
Blood sugar levels that are higher than normal but not yet diabetic. This term is used when the high blood sugar levels are found with an oral glucose tolerance test.
A test that sends sound waves to the eardrum to determine if a problem in the middle ear is causing hearing loss.
A device implanted in the chest and connected to the heart that delivers a shock to stop a potentially deadly rhythm and restore a normal (sinus) rhythm.
The inability of the penis to become firm or to stay firm enough to have sexual intercourse.
Latin for in place.
Vaccines containing microbes that have been killed, and, therefore, are unable to cause disease.
A cut made into the skin or an organ during surgery.
Involuntary passing of urine or feces.
The time between when a person is exposed to an infection and when symptoms appear.
An area of dead tissue caused by insufficient blood supply.
The death of tissue due to a lack of blood.
The growth of harmful organisms that can cause disease, such as bacteria, in the body.
Arthritis caused by harmful organisms such as bacteria.
Heart attack involving the back part of the heart-muscle wall.
The large vein that carries blood from the lower half of the body to the heart.
A cancer that has spread from where it first developed into surrounding tissue.
The body’s reaction to injury or infection. It is characterized by swelling, heat, redness, and pain.
A general term for two disorders, ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, that cause the intestines to become swollen and inflamed. Often referred to as IBD.
The slow injection of a fluid into a vein or tissues.
A condition in which the side of a toenail pierces the skin, causing pain, swelling, and sometimes infection.
A chemical that stops the transmission of a message from one nerve cell to another.
Substances injected into the skin to fill in wrinkles or add plumpness to the lips.
Inserting fluids, such as medications, into the body by means of a hollow needle and syringe.
The body’s basic defenses against disease or infection that are present from birth.
The deepest part of the ear, consisting of the cochlea and the labyrinth.
A condition that cannot be treated by surgery.
The inability to fall asleep or remain asleep long enough to feel rested.
A hormone made by the pancreas that controls the amount of glucose (sugar) in the blood.
A condition in which the body produces insulin but can’t use it properly. This leads to diabetes.
Now called type 1 diabetes. It occurs when the body doesn’t produce enough insulin to control blood sugar levels properly.
A device that emits broadband light to improve the look of the skin or remove unwanted hair.
In exercise, a measure of how hard the body is working. Cues like breathing, talking, and sweating help measure intensity through perceived exertion.
Proteins made by the body to protect against viruses, bacteria, and other harmful agents.
A group of substances that act as messengers in the immune system.
A type of lipoprotein. It consists of remnants of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) that eventually turn into low-density lipoprotein (LDL).
Pain and cramping in the legs during exercise that is caused by narrowed or blocked arteries. Also known as peripheral artery disease of the legs.
An internationally accepted amount of a substance based on its biological activity or effect; used as a measurement for fat-soluble vitamins.
Short-term talk therapy focused on identifying and addressing problems in current relationships and building social skills.
A planned, often group, meeting with a person with addiction, with the aim of overcoming denial and inducing the individual to seek treatment.
A study that compares one group that receives a medication or other therapy (an intervention) and another group does not (controls).
One of the small, shock-absorbing cushions located between the vertebrae of the spine.
The opening between vertebrae through which a spinal nerve exits the spinal column (plural: foramina).
An adverse reaction that may have similar symptoms to an allergic reaction but does not engage the immune system, and thus is not an allergy.
A hemorrhagic stroke caused by the rupture of a blood vessel and subsequent bleeding into the brain tissue.
A small artificial lens permanently fixed inside the eye to replace the natural lens during cataract surgery.
Inability of the urinary sphincter to close completely.
Salt compounds containing iodine that are used to control severe hyperthyroidism in special circumstances. They work by decreasing the thyroid gland’s production and secretion of thyroid hormone.
The colored ring in front of the lens that controls the size of the pupil and how much light enters the eye.
Substances such as tobacco, wood smoke, perfumes, and others that cause allergy-like symptoms, although the response is not an allergic reaction.
Inadequate blood supply to an organ or part of the body.
The most common form of heart disease, in which narrowed or blocked coronary arteries have difficulty supplying sections of the heart muscle with the blood they need (ischemia).
A stroke caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain; almost always caused by a blood clot blocking a blood vessel.
Clusters of hormone-producing cells, including alpha and beta cells, that appear throughout the pancreas.
A form of high blood pressure (hypertension) characterized by elevated systolic blood pressure and normal diastolic pressure.
An action in which a muscle generates force but does not contract or extend enough to move a joint, such as when pushing against an immovable object.
An actions in which a muscle generates force by contracting or lengthening to move an attached joint through its range of motion, such as lifting a dumbbell from knee-height to shoulder-height.
Commonly used abbreviation for international unit, an internationally accepted amount of a substance based on its biological activity or effect; used as a measurement for fat-soluble vitamins.
The section of the small intestine between the duodenum and the ileum.
A feeling of fatigue that occurs as the biological clock resets itself after traveling across time zones, usually by airplane.
A junction in the body where bones are linked together.
To cut food into thin, matchstick strips.
An exercise that helps prevent and treat incontinence by strengthening pelvic floor muscles.
An unusually hard or thick scar that forms after surgery or an injury.
A procedure in which a laser is used to correct vision problems by reshaping the cornea.
A protein and the major component of the cuticle and cortex layers of hair; the same protein is found in nails, feathers, claws, and hooves.
Cells of the epidermis that produce a tough protein called keratin and form a soft, protective sheet for the body.
Persistent dryness of the eye.
A skin rash that sometimes occurs along with an autoimmune condition called Reiter's syndrome.
Heart disease caused by a lack of selenium, an element that the body needs to function properly.
Substances produced when the body burns fat for energy or when the body doesn’t have enough insulin.
The final stage of chronic kidney disease. At this point, the kidneys can no longer eliminate waste products from the body.
A surgical procedure that eases or eliminates the pain of spinal fractures. It also restores vertebrae that have collapsed due to fractures to their normal size.
Blood pressure that frequently fluctuates between normal and abnormal during the course of a day, often within only a few minutes.
The inner ear. It contains the cochlea, which is responsible for hearing, as well as structures that are needed for balance.
A tear in the skin.
The gland that produces tears.
An enzyme that breaks down milk sugar (lactose) in the body.
A rare but potentially lethal condition in which blood lactic acid levels increase.
A sugar found in milk and dairy products.
The inability of the body to easily digest lactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products.
A small ischemic stroke caused by the blockage of one of the smaller blood vessels in the brain; the most common effect is weakness or disability on one side of the body.
Hard, dense tissue that forms the outer shell of bones. Also called compact bone.
One of the two thin, plate-like parts of each vertebra.
An operation in which all or part of one or both laminae is removed.
Cells of the immune system that work in the skin to fight infection.
Fine, soft hair that grows all over the body of a fetus and is typically shed before birth.
A surgical procedure carried out with tiny instruments inserted through small openings in the skin.
A concentrated beam of light; lasers are used in certain surgeries and other medical procedures.
A surgical procedure to ease snoring by removing or reshaping some of the tissues in the mouth (usually the uvula and soft palate) that vibrate and cause the noise of snoring.
Permanent hair removal technique that uses a laser to target and heat melanin in the hair shaft, which damages the hair follicle.
Surgery that uses a laser to seal off blood vessels in the eye; used to treat a number of eye diseases.
A surgical technique for treating an enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hyperplasia). It uses a high-energy laser to remove large amounts of prostate tissue with little bleeding.
An allergic reaction to the proteins found in natural rubber.
A drug or substance that induces bowel movements or makes the stool softer and looser.
Abbreviation for low-density lipoprotein. This so-called bad cholesterol can build up on artery walls, narrowing the artery and making a heart attack or stroke more likely.
When fear of not sleeping develops after a short period of not sleeping well, and this anxiety causes ongoing trouble falling or staying asleep.
Use of a panel of light-emitting diodes (LEDs) to stimulate skin cells and improve the look of the skin.
One of the main arteries that supplies blood to the heart; it runs down the front surface of the heart.
The left upper chamber of the heart.
One of the main arteries that supplies blood to the heart; it curves around the back of the heart.
The left lower chamber of the heart. It pumps blood out of the heart to other organs in the body.
A thickening of the wall of the lower left chamber of the heart, which is responsible for pumping blood to organs throughout the body.
A surgically implanted pump that augments the pumping action of the left ventricle.
A device used to check the prescription of eyeglasses.
A hormone produced by fat cells that acts on the brain to suppress appetite and burn stored fat.
An infected, diseased, or wounded area of tissue.
Asthma medications that work by blocking leukotrienes, chemicals made in the body as part of an allergic reaction.
Asthma medications that work by blocking the production or action of leukotrienes, chemicals made in the body as part of an allergic reaction.
Chemicals that cause airways to swell when an allergic reaction occurs or in diseases like asthma.
A man-made version of the thyroid hormone thyroxine.
Abbreviation for luteinizing hormone, a hormone that controls ovulation in women. In men, luteinizing hormone triggers production of testosterone.
Sexual desire.
A blood-sucking parasite known as Pediculus humanus capitis that can cause an itchy scalp; infestations are highly contagious and especially common in school-age children.
A band of tissue that connects bones.
Any material that is tied around a blood vessel to stop it from bleeding.
Antioxidant chemicals found in seeds like flax and sesame, as well as some fruits, vegetables, and grains.
A group of structures in the brain that help control memory, emotions, sexual arousal, and motivation.
The border between the cornea and the white of the eye.
A man-made version of the thyroid hormone triiodothyronine.
An enzyme secreted by the pancreas that helps the body break down fats.
Fats, oils, and waxes that serve as building blocks for cells or as energy sources. Lipids are also capable of accumulating in the artery walls to form plaque.
Dents or depressions in the skin that are caused by a loss of fatty tissue.
A buildup of fatty tissue.
A noncancerous tumor or growth composed of fat cells.
A combination of fat (lipid) and protein molecules bound together as packages. The combination allows fats and cholesterol to move easily through the blood.
A test that measures the amount of triglycerides, total cholesterol, HDL (good cholesterol), and LDL (bad cholesterol) in a person’s blood.
A molecule made up of fat and protein that is very similar to harmful LDL.
A cosmetic procedure that removes fat from an area of the body.

Vaccines made from a weakened virus or microbe. These weakened viruses and microbes don't cause disease; instead they teach the body to recognize the substance as harmful and destroy it if there is contact with it in the future.
A vital organ that removes waste products from the body and helps with digestion.
A legal document that states what a person would and wouldn’t want if he or she is no longer able to make health care decisions.
Bleeding that occurs in the white matter of the brain beneath the cerebral cortex.
A surgical procedure to severe one or more branches of nerves into the frontal lobe of the brain.
Milk-producing glands of the breast.
In reference to cancer, generally means cancer that is limited to a specific gland or other tissue, without any distant spread; an organ-confined cancer.
An area of the brain stem that helps control the brain’s alertness, responses to certain stimuli, and stress and anxiety levels.
A memory that lasts from a few minutes to decades.
A weight-loss plan that limits calories to 800–1,500 a day.
So-called bad cholesterol. If there is too much LDL in the blood, it can collect on artery walls, narrowing them and making heart attacks and strokes more likely.
A ring of muscle where the esophagus and stomach meet. It relaxes to let food into the stomach and closes to prevent stomach acids from backing up and irritating the esophagus.
A procedure in which a hollow needle is inserted into the lower part of the spinal canal to withdraw fluid for testing. Also called a spinal tap.
The lower portion of the spine. It includes the five lowermost bones (vertebrae) of the spine and is the start of the lower back.
Narrowing of the spinal canal in the lower portion of the spine (known as the lumbar spine).
The hollow part of a tube, like a blood vessel, or the cavity in a hollow organ.
A natural substance found in green leafy vegetables.
A hormone that controls ovulation in women. In men, luteinizing hormone triggers production of testosterone.
A drug that slows the production of hormones by the testicles in men or the ovaries in women.
Abbreviation for left-ventricular assist device, a surgically implanted pump that augments the pumping action of the left ventricle.
An infectious disease transmitted by a tick bite.
Small, bean-shaped organs that filter germs and foreign matter out of the body. Also called lymph glands.
A system of channels that drains excess clear fluid, called lymph, from tissues and returns it into the bloodstream.
Blockage in or damage to the lymphatic systems, causing lymphatic fluid to build up in tissues, making them swell.
A type of white blood cell that can recognize foreign substances in the body.
A type of cancer that affects cells in the lymphatic system.
The presence of larger-than-normal red blood cells in circulation—even though there are too few of them—caused by lack of folate and vitamin B12.
Substances that provide energy and that the body needs for growth. The main categories are: fat, carbohydrate, and protein.
A type of white blood cell that destroys cell debris, bacteria, and foreign agents.
The area in the center of the retina that produces sharp, clear central vision and allows one to see fine detail.
An eye disease that slowly destroys sharp, clear central vision.
The build-up of fluid in the macula caused by fluid leaking from blood vessels in the eye. It can blur and damage vision.
Swallowing too much air during a meal, causing excessive gas and discomfort. Also known as stomach bubble syndrome.

A scan that creates detailed pictures of internal organs; commonly referred to as MRI. Magnetic resonance imaging uses radio waves, a strong magnetic field, and a computer to produce images of organs and internal tissues.
A test to measure sleepiness during the day. A tester measures how long it takes a person who is sitting up in a chair or bed to fall asleep after he or she has been asked to stay awake.

Depression that interferes with daily life for an extended period. Episodes of major depression during bereavement can be distinguished from normal sadness by such symptoms as persistent feelings of worthlessness, thoughts about death, feelings of guilt, persistent trouble functioning, and marked mental and physical sluggishness.

Molecules that help protect the body from foreign substances. These molecules display proteins on the surface of cells so that protective immune system cells can kill the protein if it is harmful to the body.
An unhealthy physiological response to stressors, in which the stress response often does not turn off even when the stressor disappears.
A general feeling of illness that can be a sign of disease.
Cancerous.
A dangerous type of high blood pressure marked by an unusually sudden rise in blood pressure to very high levels, often accompanied by headache, blurred vision, and seizures.
Failure to eat or to properly absorb the nutrients needed for good health.
Abbreviation for monoamine oxidase inhibitors, medications used to treat depression. They work by making the chemical messengers serotonin and norepinephrine more available.
A cell involved in allergic reactions. When stimulated, it releases chemicals like histamine that signal infection and cause inflammation.
The bone in the skull behind the ear.
A cosmetic surgery to reshape and lift drooping breasts. Commonly known as a breast lift.
Sexual self-stimulation.
A person who typically evaluates all options before making a decision, in an effort to identify the perfect choice, and who never settles for second-best.
A detailed guide outlining the amounts and types of food a person should eat each day.
A government program that offers health care for low-income Americans of any age.
A government program that offers health care for Americans ages 65 and older.
Health insurance policies that fill in the holes in Medicare coverage.
Refers to the middle of something.
Fewer than normal healthy red blood cells in circulation, caused by a lack of folate or vitamin B12. Red cells become large and deformed, and are unable to carry oxygen efficiently.
A type of medication taken to treat type 2 diabetes.
A substance that gives the skin, hair, and eyes their natural color.
Cells located deep in the epidermis that produce melanin, the pigment that colors skin.
The most dangerous type of skin cancer.
A hormone that regulates the body’s sleep-wake cycle.
A thin layer of tissue that surrounds or lines organs or cavities.

term: memory T cells and B cells
explanation: Immune cells that remember harmful agents that have entered the body in the past. When they spot the substance again, they spur the immune system to eliminate the invader.
An illness caused by a fluid imbalance in the inner ear.
The three membranes that cover and protect the brain and spinal cord.
Swelling of the membranes that cover and protect the brain and spinal cord.
The point marking the end of menstruation, officially designated as one year after a woman’s final period.
Units used to estimate the oxygen consumption, or metabolic cost, of physical activity, and, hence, its intensity. One metabolic equivalent (MET) is the estimated energy cost of the body at rest.
A cluster of risk factors that accelerate the progression of heart disease.
The chemical reactions that occur in all living organisms to maintain life. An example is converting food into energy that the body needs to function.
The spread of cancer cells from the primary site to another part of the body.
A device that delivers a specific dose of an inhaled asthma medication.
Bacteria in the gut that help with the digestion of complex sugars.

Abbreviation for metabolic equivalents, units used to estimate the oxygen consumption, or metabolic cost, of physical activity, and, hence, its intensity. One MET is the estimated energy cost of the body at rest.

Abbreviation for major histocompatibility complex molecule, molecules that help protect the body from foreign substances. These molecules display proteins on the surface of cells so that protective immune system cells can kill the protein if it is harmful to the body.
Leakage of small amounts of a protein called albumin into the urine caused by kidney disease or damage.
A tiny bulge that develops in the wall of a blood vessel.
A microorganism.
A cosmetic procedure in which tiny crystals under high pressure are sprayed on the face. This buffs away the outer layer of skin, eliminates fine lines, and improves the look of the skin.
A unit of mass, equal to one-thousandth of a milligram. Abbreviated as mcg.
Reducing a substance to very small particles.
Vitamins and minerals needed to maintain normal body functions and prevent certain illnesses.
A condition in which the smallest blood vessels in the walls of the heart are narrowed or inelastic.
The body's small blood vessels.
Emptying the bladder. Also called urination or voiding.
The air-filled cavity behind the eardrum that contains the three small bones that transmit sound vibrations to the inner ear.
A severe headache with pain that usually begins on one side of the head. Symptoms may include visual disturbances (called aura), nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or noise.
A severe headache preceded by visual disturbances such as flashing lights, seeing lines, or a blind spot.
A severe headache that is not preceded by visual disturbances such as flashing lights. Also known as common migraine.
The loss of some brain functions, such as memory, thinking, or language, that is noticeable, but doesn’t interfere with ability to carry out daily tasks.
A metric unit of weight equivalent to one-thousandth of a gram. Abbreviated as mg.
A practice with its roots in Buddhism that encourages people to be more fully aware of the present moment. Often achieved through meditation.

A form of meditation with roots in ancient Buddhist practice through which a person has a calm awareness of his or her body and feelings and is fully engaged in the present; also called insight meditation.
A well-established acceptance-based therapy, used principally in treatment of depression and anxiety.
Acting without full attention to one's surroundings, behavior, or internal experience.
An eye drop that constricts the pupil; used to treat glaucoma.
Small structures within cells that create break down nutrients and create energy for cells. Known as the power producers or energy factories of cells.
The valve that controls the one-way flow of blood from the left atrium to the left ventricle.
A valve problem in which one or both of the mitral valve flaps collapse backward into the left atrium. This may allow a small amount of blood to leak backward (regurgitate) through the valve.
A narrowing of the mitral valve opening that limits blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle.
Medications used to treat depression. They work by making the chemical messengers serotonin and norepinephrine more available.
An antibody is a protein molecule that can bind to a virus and mark it for destruction by the immune system. A monoclonal antibody is a man-made substance used to treat some viral and other diseases.
White blood cells that protect the body from disease by attacking and consuming foreign particles.
A type of fat abundant in vegetable oils such as olive, peanut, sesame, and canola oils. Monounsaturated fats don’t raise levels of unhealthy LDL cholesterol, and may even lower it.
A thickening of nerve tissue between the toes that causes irritation, tingling, or a burning pain in the ball of the foot.
A hormone that helps the small intestine contract and move food through the digestive tract.
The ability of the digestive tract to move its contents.
A nerve cell that directs activity in a specific group of muscle fibers.
The pairing of a nerve cell and the group of muscle fibers it commands.

Abbreviation for magnetic resonance imaging--a scan that creates detailed pictures of internal organs. MRIs use radio waves, a strong magnetic field, and a computer to produce images of organs and internal tissues.
Tissue that lines the tube-like structures of the body such as the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.
Small cysts that form between the nail bed and the top joint of the finger.
A thin layer that lines many cavities and structures in the body that are exposed to air in the environment, such as the nose, mouth, and lungs.
Memory loss and impaired thinking caused by tiny strokes that are often too small to notice until a sizable area of the brain is affected.
An enlargement of the thyroid gland with more than one lump or nodule appearing on the neck.
An autoimmune disease in which the body’s immune system mistakenly attacks myelin, the substance that covers nerve fibers.
A sleep test to measure daytime sleepiness. It times how quickly a person falls asleep when asked to rest in a quiet, darkened room during the day.
An sound heard during an examination of the heart caused by abnormal flow of blood through heart chambers or valves. Many heart murmurs do not indicate heart problems; others do.
Weakness felt in muscles when they have been tired out.
Cells bundled together to make up muscle tissue. Also known as muscle cells.
A headache characterized by constant pressure, mild to moderate pain, and the feeling that a tight band is squeezing the head. Also known as a tension headache.
The ability of muscle to continue to perform without stopping because of fatigue.
The thin layer of smooth muscle lining of the colon or rectum.
Related to the muscles and the skeleton.
Abbreviation for medicated urethral system for erection. In this therapy, a small drug pellet is inserted into the tip of the penis to produce an erection.
The process by which a change occurs in genetic material and is inherited by the next generation.
Pain or tenderness in a muscle.
An abnormal weakness in a muscle or group of muscles.
A type of drug that widens the pupil.
A fatty material that surrounds and protects some nerve fibers.

A test that uses a special dye and X-rays to detect spinal cord problems. The dye is injected into the space surrounding the spinal cord, making the spinal cord, spinal canal, and nerve roots appear in detail on the X-ray.
A disorder in which the spinal cord is compressed, diseased, or damaged.
Medical term for heart attack, the sudden death of part of the heart muscle from lack of oxygen.
Tearing of one of the walls of the heart. It usually occurs immediately after a heart attack.
Inflammation of the heart muscle (myocardium).
The middle layer of heart tissue. The muscular myocardium is sandwiched between the outer layer (epicardium) and the inner layer (endocardium).
A muscle cell.
Long interlocking strands that make up muscle fibers.
The fundamental muscle proteins that form myofibrils. Myofilaments slide over one another, bunching up and generating force, when a muscle contracts.
Nearsightedness. An optical error in which light rays meet and focus before reaching the retina, making objects that are far away appear blurry.
A protein that helps muscle contract and relax.
A small quantity of a substance; equivalent to one-billionth of a gram (454 grams make 1 pound) in one-thousandth of a liter (1 liter is approximately 1 quart). Abbreviated as ng/ml.
A sleep disorder that causes extreme sleepiness and uncontrollable sleep attacks, making a person fall asleep at inappropriate times during the day.
Lines in the skin leading from the nose to the outer corners of the mouth. Also known as smile or laugh lines.
A type of white blood cell of the immune system. These cells destroy other cells that fail to display the right chemical flags signaling that they are normal cells.
People who overcome addiction without treatment or formal self-help programs.
A device that converts a liquid medicine into a mist that can be breathed in.
The premature death of living cells or tissues.
Use of a hollow needle to remove a small sample of tissue for examination.
A helper treatment given before a primary treatment is started, such as when chemotherapy is done before surgery in order to shrink a tumor.
Relating to an infant younger than 4 weeks of age.
An abnormal growth of tissue, either cancerous or benign.
Inflammation of the kidneys.
Kidney disease.
Injection of a medication into one or more nerves to relieve pain.
A molecule in the body that promotes the growth and repair of nerve cells.
When referring to prostatectomy, the surgical procedure that preserves the nerves needed to allow the penis to become erect.
A burning or stabbing pain that follows the path of a nerve.
Clumps of sticky proteins found in the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease.
Twisted strands of proteins that are found inside the dead or dying nerve cells of people with Alzheimer's disease.
Powerful tranquilizing drugs used to treat schizophrenia.
A physician trained to diagnose and treat disorders of the nervous system, including the brain and spinal cord.
The tiny space between the end of a nerve and the surface of a muscle.
A nerve cell.
Nerve damage and resulting loss of sensation, movement, or other function.
Small proteins that aid in transmitting signals between nerve cells.
A rare infection of the brain or spinal cord that occurs when syphilis goes untreated for many years.
A chemical messenger released by nerve cells that transmits messages to nearby other nerve cells.

Cell structures (usually proteins) that recognize specific neurotransmitters and bind to them. Once bound, a receptor often changes shape, causing a cascade of chemical events within the cell. These events can alter which genes are turned on or off and can make the cell more or less likely to release its neurotransmitters.
Keeping the body in a straight line from head to toe except for the slight natural curves of the spine.
A standing or seated position in which the chin is parallel to the floor; the shoulders, hips, and knees are at even heights; and the knees and feet point straight ahead.
A position in which the back is straight except for the slight natural curves of the spine.
An abnormally low number of white blood cells.
White blood cells that seek out and engulf foreign cells.
Medications that widen blood vessels; usually used to treat chest pain from angina and other heart problems.

A compound produced by the endothelium (the lining of the interior walls of arteries) that helps widen blood vessels and counteract high blood pressure. Also called endothelium-derived relaxing factor.
A drug that relaxes blood vessels and increases the supply of blood and oxygen to the heart while reducing its workload. It is commonly used to treat angina.

Abbreviation for natural killer cells, a type of white blood cell of the immune system. These cells destroy other cells that fail to display the right chemical flags signaling that they are normal cells.
Abbreviation for the N-methyl-D-aspartame receptor, a molecule on the surface of a brain cell that admits calcium when activated by the chemical messenger glutamate.
A molecule on the surface of a brain cell that admits calcium when activated by the chemical messenger glutamate.

Abbreviation for nitric oxide, a compound produced by the endothelium (the lining of the interior walls of arteries) that helps widen blood vessels and counteract high blood pressure. Also called endothelium-derived relaxing factor.
Nerve endings that detect pain and transmit pain information to the brain and spinal cord.
Waking up more than once during the night to urinate.
A small rounded bump or knot of tissue.
A chart or graph of mathematical calculations of risk; used in making treatment recommendations and predicting outcomes.
The sum of all cholesterol types other than high-density lipoprotein (HDL). These include very-low-density lipoprotein, low-density lipoprotein, and intermediate-density lipoprotein.

Now called type 2 diabetes. A disease in which levels of blood sugar (glucose) are too high initially because cells can’t properly use insulin (a hormone that helps cells absorb glucose from the bloodstream). Over time the production of insulin may decline.
A test that does not require any medical instruments to break the skin or enter the body.

A rare and very serious condition associated with type 2 diabetes. Symptoms include extremely high (more than 800 mg/dl) blood sugar levels, severe dehydration, and changes in mental status, ultimately resulting in coma.
A condition in which the walls of the small blood vessels in the retina leak serum and tiny pockets of swelling form in the walls of blood vessels. Also called background retinopathy.
The sleep phase that includes deep sleep, the type considered most important for preventing daytime sleepiness.
A drug that reduces swelling and pain.
A hormone produced by adrenal glands that puts the body on heightened alert when a threat is perceived (the fight-or-flight response). Also known as norepinephrine.
A hormone produced by adrenal glands that puts the body on heightened alert when a threat is perceived (the fight-or-flight response). Also known as noradrenaline.
A buildup of fluid in the brain that causes the brain to swell, and leads to slowing of mental function, trouble walking, and a loss of bladder control.
Abbreviation for nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, a drug that reduce swelling and pain.
Tests that use tiny amounts of short-lived radioactive substances that can target particular organs or cell receptors to diagnose disease.
Part of the brain’s reward pathway that is most tightly and consistently responsive to pleasure. Also known as the pleasure center.
The gel-like shock-absorbing central portion of each spinal disc.
Dietary supplement containing concentrated forms of a presumed bioactive substance originally derived from food and used to enhance health in dosages exceeding those normally obtainable from food.
Substances in foods that the body needs to survive.
A body weight that is much higher than is healthy. Defined as having a body mass index of 30 or more. Obesity puts a person at greater risk of developing numerous chronic diseases.
The psychoactive drug or rewarding behavior with which a person with addiction has a pathological relationship.
A disorder marked by heavy snoring and interrupted breathing during sleep. It increases the risk of developing high blood pressure and having a stroke and is more common in people who are obese.
The region in the back of the brain responsible for visual processing.
The closing or blocking of a hollow organ or body part.
Something not visible to the naked eye but seen under a microscope or through lab tests.
Beneficial fats, also known as n-3 fatty acids. These are polyunsaturated fat found in fatty fish, such as salmon.
Fatty acids found in certain foods that the body needs for good health but can’t make on its own. Also known as n-6 fatty acids.
A gene that, under certain conditions, can cause cancer.
A physician who deals with the diagnosis and treatment of cancer. There are three types—medical oncologists, radiation oncologists, and surgical oncologists.
A rare and potentially fatal disorder in which a person may stop breathing, especially at night. Also called congenital central hypoventilation syndrome.
Toenail fungus.
A surgical procedure in which an enlarged prostate is removed through an incision in the abdomen.
A physician who specializes in treating the eye and eye disease.
An instrument with a light and mirrors for examining the deep interior of the eye.
Any painkilling drug such as morphine or codeine derived from the opium poppy.
Any narcotic, natural or synthetic, that behaves in the body like an opium-derived drug.
The front surface of the optic nerve, where all the retinal nerve fibers come together to carry an image to the brain.
A cable of specialized nerve fibers that transmit visual impulses from the eye to the brain.
A technician who helps select and fit eyeglasses or contact lenses for people with vision problems.
A characteristic frame of mind that leads a person to expect positive outcomes and to view the world as a positive place.
A health care professional licensed to examine the eye, and diagnose and treat some eye diseases.
A test to check for diabetes. It involves fasting overnight and having blood sugar levels checked before and after drinking a sugary solution.
The layer of soft pinkish tissue that lines the interior of the mouth.
The bony socket that holds the eyeball.
X-ray treatment to the eye; sometimes used in more serious cases of Graves’ eye disease.
Surgery to remove the testicles. Usually done to remove a cancerous testicle or to lower testosterone levels and slow or halt the growth of prostate cancer.
The protein framework of bone tissue.
A chemical found in cruciferous vegetables that may have anti-cancer properties.
The series of pleasurable, rhythmic muscle contractions that mark the peak of sexual arousal and the release of muscle tension.
A medical doctor who specializes in correcting disorders of the bones, joints, muscles, and tendons.
A custom shoe insert that helps cushion or realign the foot.
A sudden drop in blood pressure upon standing or getting out of bed, causing dizziness.
A process in which bone heals around an implant to create a stable anchor.
Three bones in the middle ear that move in response to sound vibrations.
The process by which bone is formed.
A joint disease in which the cartilage that lines the joints slowly deteriorates. Also called degenerative joint disease.
Cells that build bone tissue.
Cells that remove bone tissue.
A cell that is embedded in fully formed bone.
A condition in which bones are soft and weak, usually due to a lack of vitamin D or an inability of the body to use vitamin D properly.
A bone infection caused by bacteria or fungi.
The building blocks of compact bone, the hard, tightly-packed tissue that forms the outer shell of bones.

A doctor licensed to practice medicine, perform surgery, and prescribe drugs. The training is similar to that of a regular M.D., but more emphasis is placed on the importance of the musculoskeletal system and the body’s ability to heal itself.
Mild thinning and weakening of the bones; bone density is lower than normal but not low enough to be classified as osteoporosis.
An outgrowth of bone on a joint or spinal disk; commonly called a bone spur.
Significant thinning and weakening of bones over time, making them vulnerable to breaks.
An operation in which bone is cut to change its alignment or shorten or lengthen it.
The bony shell that surrounds the inner ear.
An infection of the skin lining the ear canal of the outer ear. Also called swimmer’s ear.
An infection of the middle ear.
An abnormal bony growth in the middle ear that causes hearing loss.
Synonymous with epidemic. Sometimes used to refer to a local epidemic as compared to a larger, general epidemic.
The external part of the ear, as well as the external ear canal and the eardrum.
A person who receives treatment at a hospital or other medical facility but does not stay overnight.
The loudest sound that a hearing aid can produce.
Surgical removal of one or both ovaries.
Frequent urination and urges to urinate.

A condition of declining kidney function. It is part of the progression of kidney disease, developing after microalbuminuria (when a damaged kidney begins to leak small amounts of a protein called albumin into urine) and before chronic kidney disease.
A body weight above the healthy range but not obese. Usually defined as a body mass index of 25 to 29.9.
The release of a mature egg from the ovary, at which time it is available to be fertilized by sperm.
An unstable molecule in the body that plays a role in aging and can damage tissue. Also known as a free radical.
A process in which oxygen combines with a substance, altering its structure and changing or destroying its normal function.
Blood that has moved through the lungs where it has absorbed oxygen; oxygenated blood moves from the lungs into the heart, from which it is then pumped throughout the body.
A small electronic device generally placed in the chest to correct an irregular heartbeat. It generates small electrical pulses that prompt the heart to beat at a normal pace.

A specialized cluster of cells called the sinoatrial node in the top of the right atrium. The pacemaker produces a steady flow of beat now signals that flash across the atria and then pass through the atrioventricular node to the ventricles.
Abbreviation for peripheral artery disease, a condition caused by atherosclerosis in the arteries in the legs or leading to them.
Drugs that relieve pain.
The tissues that make up the roof of the mouth.
Treatment that relieves the symptoms of a serious illness, but does not cure the disease itself.
To examine a part of the body by touching it carefully.
Sensation that the heart is beating rapidly or irregularly.
Paralysis in part of the body, often with loss of sensation and uncontrolled body movements.
A gland in the abdomen that produces digestive enzymes and hormones.
A disease outbreak affecting large populations or a whole region, country, or continent.
An abnormal layer of tissue that forms over joints or the cornea of the eye.
Threads of muscle that pull the heart valves between the upper and lower chambers of the heart closed during heart contractions.
Paralysis of the legs and lower part of the body.
Sleep disorders, such as night terrors or sleep walking, that periodically interfere with sleep.
Part of the nervous system that calms body systems excited by the stress hormones.
Glands responsible for releasing a hormone that controls calcium levels and influences bone loss and growth.
A hormone that controls levels of calcium and phosphorous in the blood and influences bone loss and growth.
Part of the brain. It plays a role in sensory processes, like pain and touch, and language.
A brain disorder that causes movement problems, including shaking, difficulty walking, and rigidity in muscles.
A sudden, violent attack or convulsion; or the worsening of symptoms or recurrence of disease.
A rare form of headache. Sufferers experience a severe throbbing, drilling pain on one side of the face or behind the eye.
Immunity that is conferred by another, such as a mother’s antibodies protecting her baby during gestation and shortly after birth.
A test used to diagnose whether a rash was caused by a reaction to certain allergens, such as poison ivy or a cosmetic ingredient, or an irritant such as soap.
The thick bone that protects the knee joint; also known as the kneecap.
A tiny organism such as a virus, bacterium, or parasite that can invade the body and produce disease.
The underlying abnormalities that contribute to or are characteristic of a disease.

A method that allows a person to control, within limits, the amount and timing of pain medication he or she receives. It is usually done by pressing a button to release the medication from a computerized pump into an IV.
Proteins that recognize classes of pathogens and stimulate the innate immune system to signal the adaptive immune system.

Abbreviation for polycystic ovary syndrome, an inherited disorder characterized by the formation of abnormal cysts in enlarged ovaries; a leading cause of female infertility and a common cause of excess facial or body hair (hirsutism).
Abbreviation for phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors, drugs that can help a man achieve and maintain an erection.
The greatest amount of bone tissue that a person has during his or her life.
A measure of how fast a person can blow air out of the lungs.
A device to assess lung function, often used to diagnose and monitor asthma.
A blood-sucking parasite commonly known as the louse (plural, lice) that can cause an itchy scalp; infestations are highly contagious and especially common in school-age children.
A rare disease brought on by severe niacin deficiency that causes diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia.

The sling of muscles that support the intestines and bladder, as well as the uterus in women. Weak or damaged pelvic floor muscles can cause incontinence or diminished sexual pleasure, among other problems.
An inflatable or bendable device that is implanted in the penis to allow a man with erectile dysfunction to have erections when he wishes.
Enzymes secreted by the stomach to break down protein.
A raw, crater-like sore in the lining of the stomach or duodenum that causes burning stomach pain.
Surgical removal of part of a spinal disk that is bulging out abnormally and pressing on a nerve root or the spinal column.
A pain relief therapy that uses needles to deliver low-voltage electrical current under the skin to stop pain signals from reaching the brain.

A procedure used to open blocked coronary arteries. A small, thin tube with a tiny balloon at its tip is inserted into a narrowed coronary artery. The balloon is then inflated to widen the narrowed area. A stent may be put in place to hold the artery open. Percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty is also known as balloon angioplasty.
A hole, such as an ulcer, in an organ or tissue.
Concern about sexual performance that is so severe that it leads to sexual dysfunction.
Passage of a fluid through a specific organ or an area of the body.
A test result that indicates abnormal blood flow or areas of damaged or dead heart muscle.
Inflammation of the pericardium, the heart's sac-like covering.
The fibrous sac that surrounds the heart and the roots of the major blood vessels.
The transition time in a woman’s life that begins when ovaries produce less estrogen and menstruation becomes less frequent, and ends when the ovaries no longer produce eggs and menstruation stops.
The area of skin between the vagina and anus in women, and between the scrotum and anus in men.
A sleep disorder in which the legs jerk or cramp repeatedly during the sleep.
An exercise strategy that varies reps, sets, and resistance to alternate heavier and lighter workouts over a period of time.
Diseases, including gingivitis and periodontitis, that attack the gum tissue and the structures supporting the teeth. Also called gum disease.
An advanced stage of gum disease that attacks the teeth’s supporting structures.
A condition caused by atherosclerosis in the arteries in the legs or leading to them.
The parts of the nervous system outside of the brain, brain stem, and spinal cord.
Damage to the long nerves radiating from the spine to the arms and legs.
Narrowing of blood vessels that supply blood to the legs, arms, stomach, or kidneys.
Side vision, or what the eye perceives outside the direct line of vision.
Wavelike movement of intestinal muscles that propels food through the digestive tract.
Treatment for kidney failure that uses a machine to remove toxins from the bloodstream.
Inflammation of the membrane that line the abdominal cavity and surrounds most abdominal organs.
A form of anemia in which red blood cells enlarge and decrease in size due to an inability to properly absorb vitamin B12.
A device worn around the neck or wrist that allows a person to call for help by pressing a button.
A device placed in the vagina to support or correct the position of the uterus, rectum, or bladder.
A characteristic frame of mind that leads a person to expect negative outcomes and to view the world as a negative or fearful place.
Pinpoint-sized red or purple spots that appear in clusters on the skin, caused by bleeding under the skin.
Abbreviation for positron emission tomography, a medical imaging test that uses a radioactive substance to assess organ and tissue function in the body and to look for disease.
Scarring of some of the tissue inside the penis, causing the penis to bend at an angle during an erection.
A test to determine whether stomach acid is backing up into the esophagus. For this test, a sensing probe is inserted through the nose and positioned above the lower esophageal sphincter.
A method of cataract removal. It uses ultrasound waves to break up the clouded lens of the eye so it can be suctioned out with a needle.
Cells that can ingest other cells, bacteria, and foreign particles.
Sleep problem that results when a person's internal clock becomes out of sync with external time. This can be a problem for people who work the night shift.
A helpful enzyme that seems to clear toxins and help prevent cancer-causing substances from binding to DNA.
Powerful tranquilizing drugs used to treat schizophrenia and, sometimes, severe nausea.
A decongestant drug used to treat nasal congestion and sometimes mild incontinence.
A rare adrenal gland tumor that secretes hormones that narrow blood vessels and increase blood pressure.
Thick, sticky mucus secreted by mucous membranes, such as the sinuses.
Sensitivity to noise, often experienced during a migraine attack.
An enzyme that breaks down substances that help the penis become erect and maintain an erection.
Use of a laser to seal off blood vessels.
A medical treatment that uses a light source to activate a photosensitizing drug (one that becomes activated by light exposure). Often used in oncology, dermatology, and cosmetic surgery.
Sensitivity to light, often experienced during a migraine attack.
A sensation of sparks or flashes of light across the visual field.
Laser surgery used to reshape the cornea in order to correct vision problems.
A cosmetic procedure that uses intense pulsed light to remove wrinkles and improve skin tone and texture.

A physician who specializes in physical medicine, pain, and rehabilitation. These doctors diagnose and treat sports injuries and degenerative conditions like arthritis or low back pain, and oversee rehab for patients with severe impairments resulting from trauma, stroke, and other conditions.
Any voluntary body movements that burn calories, including walking up stairs, vacuuming a floor, going for a brisk stroll, or engaging in a structured program of exercise.

The process through which the body becomes accustomed to a psychoactive drug or rewarding behavior and misses it if it’s taken away. People with physical dependence who stop or cut down on their substance or activity of choice might develop uncomfortable withdrawal symptoms.
A state of being physically sound and healthy; having the ability to perform physical activity well.
Substances made by plants that have biological effects in the human body. Examples include isoflavones, lycopene, lutein, and zeaxanthin.
A plant component that mimics the effects of estrogen hormones in the body.
A brain disorder that causes dementia, neurotic behavior, and gradual changes in personality and emotional control.
A gland located in the middle of the brain, between the brain’s two hemispheres, that produces melatonin in response to declining light.
A substance that binds to amyloid proteins in the brain (markers for Alzheimer’s disease), making them visible under positron emission tomography (PET) scanning.
The so-called master gland, located at the base of the brain. It controls and regulates the thyroid and other glands throughout the endocrine system.
A false or inactive medication or treatment that may still offer relief despite being ineffective. In clinical trials, the effectiveness of a new drug is often tested against a placebo.
A change or improvement in symptoms that is due to a dummy medication or treatment (placebo) rather than a real drug or treatment.
Connective tissue in the foot which joins the heel bone to the ball of the foot.
An inflammation of the plantar fascia; the leading cause of heel pain.
A wart on the sole of the foot, caused by a virus.
1) A layer of bacteria that forms on the surface of a tooth and can cause dental disease. 2) A fatty deposit in or on the walls of an artery, as part of atherosclerosis.
The fluid in which blood cells are suspended.
White blood cells that produce large quantities of antibodies as part of an immune system response.
An enzyme that breaks down the protein involved in clotting blood (fibrin), dissolving the clot.
A colorless, disk-shaped cell in the blood that is necessary for clotting.
A physician who specializes in the medical, surgical, and orthopedic management of foot and ankle disorders.
A localized patch of gray or white hair on the scalp, eyebrows, or eyelashes.
An inherited disorder characterized by the formation of abnormal cysts in enlarged ovaries; a leading cause of female infertility and a common cause of hirsutism.
Excessive thirst.
A rare disease in which the muscles become inflamed and weak.
An abnormal, noncancerous growth that protrudes from mucous membranes, like those found in the sinuses and colon lining.
A sleep study that examines brain waves and other measures of physiological functioning.
A type of fat that is abundant in soybean, corn, cottonseed, safflower, and sunflower oils, as well as in fatty fish. One type, omega-3 fats, are especially important for cardiovascular health.
Excessive urination.
A branch of psychology that studies mental health rather than illness, focusing on how life can be more happy and fulfilling.
A medical imaging test that uses a radioactive substance to assess organ and tissue function in the body and to look for disease. Commonly called a PET scan.
The part of the eye behind the iris and in front of the lens that is filled with aqueous humor.
An inflammation of the bursa sac surrounding the joint in the heel of the foot, causing swelling and pain.
A minimally invasive surgical procedure that is sometimes an option for repairing a herniated disk.
Heart attack involving the rear wall of the heart muscle.
Nerve pain caused by the herpes zoster virus, also known as shingles.
Bone loss caused by lower estrogen levels associated with menopause. Sometimes called type I osteoporosis.
The period in a woman's life lasting from the end of perimenopause until the end of life.
Pertaining to the period after giving birth.
A persistent headache resulting from a head or neck injury, sometimes lasting for a year or more.

A prolonged reaction to a traumatic event. Post-traumatic stress disorder can cause crippling anxiety and leading to other problems, such as sleep disturbances, depression, and substance abuse. Often referred to as PTSD.
The amount of urine left in the bladder after urinating.
Force times speed of movement. It reflects how quickly a given force is exerted.
An emerging field of physical medicine aimed at boosting the ability to exert strength quickly, especially in relation to practical, day-to-day tasks.
A member of a class of drugs called alpha blockers. Prazosin eases the symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia by relaxing smooth muscle tissue in the capsule that surrounds the prostate.
A substance that the body can convert into the active form of a vitamin. One example is beta carotene, which the body can convert into vitamin A as needed.
A fasting blood sugar level above a healthy level, but still below the level used to diagnose diabetes. An individual with prediabetes is at increased risk for developing diabetes.
